\b \cf0 Chapter 11. 
\b0 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Sixty seconds. That\'92s how long we\'92re required to stand on our metal circles before the sound of a gong releases us. Step off before the minute is up, and land mines blow your legs off. Sixty seconds to take in the ring of tributes all equidistant from the Cornucopia, a giant golden horn shaped like a cone with a curved tail, the mouth of which is at least twenty feet high, spilling over with the things that will give us life here in the arena. Food, containers of water, weapons, medicine, garments, fire starters. Strewn around the Cornucopia are other supplies, their value decreasing the farther they are from the horn. For instance, only a few steps from my feet lays a three-foot square of plastic. Certainly it could be of some use in a downpour. But there in the mouth, I can see a tent pack that would protect from almost any sort of weather. If I had the guts to go in and fight for it against the other twenty-three tributes. Which I have been instructed not to do. \
We\'92re on a flat, open stretch of ground. A plain of hard-packed dirt. Behind the tributes across from me, I can see nothing, indicating either a steep downward slope or even cliff. To my right lies a lake. To my left and \
back, spars piney woods. This is where Haymitch would want me to go. Immediately. \
I hear his instructions in my head. \'93Just clear out, put as much distance as you can between yourselves and the others, and find a source of water.\'94 \
But it\'92s tempting, so tempting, when I see the bounty waiting there before me. And I know that if I don\'92t get it, someone else will. That the Career Tributes who survive the bloodbath will divide up most of these life-sustaining spoils. Something catches my eye. There, resting on a mound of blanket rolls, is a silver sheath of arrows and a bow, already strung, just waiting to be engaged. That\'92s mine, I think. It\'92s meant for me. \
I\'92m fast. I can sprint faster than any of the girls in our school although a couple can beat me in distance races. But this forty-yard length, this is what I am built for. I know I can get it, I know I can reach it first, but then the question is how quickly can I get out of there? By the time I\'92ve scrambled up the packs and grabbed the weapons, others will have reached the horn, and one or two I might be able to pick off, but say there\'92s a dozen, at that close range, they could take me down with the \
spears and the clubs. Or their own powerful fists. \
Still, I won\'92t be the only target. I\'92m betting many of the other tributes would pass up a smaller girl, even one who scored an eleven in training, to take out their more fierce adversaries. \
Haymitch has never seen me run. Maybe if he had he\'92d tell me to go for it. Get the weapon. Since that\'92s the very weapon that might be my salvation. And I only see one bow in that whole pile. I know the minute must be almost up and will have to decide what my strategy will be and I find myself positioning my feet to run, not away into the stir rounding forests but toward the pile, toward the bow. When suddenly I notice Peeta, he\'92s about five tributes to my right, quite a fair distance, still I can tell he\'92s looking at me and I think he might be shaking his head. But the sun\'92s in my eyes, and while I\'92m puzzling over it the gong rings out. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 And I\'92ve missed it! I\'92ve missed my chance! Because those extra couple of seconds I\'92ve lost by not being ready are enough to change my mind about going in. My feet shuffle for a moment, confused at the direction my brain wants to take and then I lunge forward, scoop up \
the sheet of plastic and a loaf of bread. The pickings are so small and I\'92m so angry with Peeta for distracting me that I sprint in twenty yards to retrieve a bright orange backpack that could hold anything because I can\'92t stand leaving with virtually nothing. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 A boy, I think from District 9, reaches the pack at the same time I do and for a brief time we grapple for it and then he coughs, splattering my face with blood. I stagger back, repulsed by the warm, sticky spray. Then the boy slips to the ground. That\'92s when I see the knife in his back. Already other tributes have reached the Cornucopia and are spreading out to attack. Yes, the girl from District 2, ten yards away, running toward me, one hand clutching a half-dozen knives. I\'92ve seen her throw in training. She never misses. And I\'92m her next target. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 All the general fear I\'92ve been feeling condenses into at immediate fear of this girl, this predator who might kill me in seconds. Adrenaline shoots through me and I sling the pack over one shoulder and run full-speed for the woods. I can hear the blade whistling toward me and reflexively hike the pack up to protect my head. The blade lodges in the pack. Both straps on my shoulders now, I make for the trees. Somehow I know the girl will \
not pursue me. That she\'92ll be drawn back into the Cornucopia before all the good stuff is gone. A grin crosses my face. Thanks for the knife, I think. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 At the edge of the woods I turn for one instant to survey the field. About a dozen or so tributes are hacking away at one another at the horn. Several lie dead already on the ground. Those who have taken flight are disappearing into the trees or into the void opposite me. I continue running until the woods have hidden me from the other tributes then slow into a steady jog that I think I can maintain for a while. For the next few hours, I alternate between jogging and walking, putting as much distance as I can between myself and my competitors. I lost my bread during the struggle with the boy from District 9 but managed to stuff my plastic in my sleeve so as I walk I fold it neatly and tuck it into a pocket. I also free the knife \'97 it\'92s a fine one with a long sharp blade, serrated near the handle, which will make it handy for sawing through things \'97 and slide it into my belt. I don\'92t dare stop to examine the contents of the pack yet. I just keep moving, pausing only to check for pursuers. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I can go a long time. I know that from my days in the woods. But I will need water. That was Haymitch\'92s \
second instruction, and since I sort of botched the first, I keep a sharp eye out for any sign of it. No luck. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 The woods begin to evolve, and the pines are intermixed with a variety of trees, some I recognize, some completely foreign to me. At one point, I hear a noise and pull my knife, thinking I may have to defend myself, but I\'92ve only startled a rabbit. \'93Good to see you,\'94 I whisper. If there\'92s one rabbit, there could be hundreds just waiting to be snared. \
The ground slopes down. I don\'92t particularly like this. Valleys make me feel trapped. I want to be high, like in the hills around District 12, where I can see my enemies approaching. But I have no choice but to keep going. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 Funny though, I don\'92t feel too bad. The days of gorging myself have paid off. I\'92ve got staying power even though I\'92m short on sleep. Being in the woods is rejuvenating. I\'92m glad for the solitude, even though it\'92s an illusion, because I\'92m probably on-screen right now. Not consistently but off and on. There are so many deaths to show the first day that a tribute trekking through the woods isn\'92t much to look at. But they\'92ll show me enough to let people know I\'92m alive, uninjured and on the move. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 One of the heaviest days of betting is the opening, when the initial casualties come in. But that can\'92t compare to what happens as the field shrinks to a handful of players. \
It\'92s late afternoon when I begin to hear the cannons. Each shot represents a dead tribute. The fighting must have finally stopped at the Cornucopia. They never collect the bloodbath bodies until the killers have dispersed. On the opening day, they don\'92t even fire the cannons until the initial fighting\'92s over because it\'92s too hard to keep track of the fatalities. I allow myself to pause, panting, as I count the shots. One . . . two . . . three . . . on and on until they reach eleven. Eleven dead in all. Thirteen left to play. My fingernails scrape at the dried blood the boy from District 9 coughed into my face. He\'92s gone, certainly. I wonder about Peeta. Has he lasted through the day? I\'92ll know in a few hours. When they project the dead\'92s images into the sky for the rest of us to see. \
All of a sudden, I\'92m overwhelmed by the thought that Peeta may be already lost, bled white, collected, and in the process of being transported back to the Capitol to be cleaned up, redressed, and shipped in a simple wooden box back to District 12. No longer here. Heading home. I \
try hard to remember if I saw him once the action started. But the last image I can conjure up is Peeta shaking his head as the gong rang out. Maybe it\'92s better, if he\'92s gone already. He had no confidence he could win. And I will not end up with the unpleasant task of killing him. Maybe it\'92s better if he\'92s out of this for good. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I slump down next to my pack, exhausted. I need to go through it anyway before night falls. See what I have to work with. As I unhook the straps, I can feel it\'92s sturdily made although a rather unfortunate color. This orange will practically glow in the dark. I make a mental note to camouflage it first thing tomorrow. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I flip open the flap. What I want most, right at this moment, is water. Haymitch\'92s directive to immediately find water was not arbitrary. I won\'92t last long without it. For a few days, I\'92ll be able to function with unpleasant symptoms of dehydration, but after that I'll deteriorate into helplessness and be dead in a week, tops. I carefully lay out the provisions. One thin black sleeping bag that reflects body heat. A pack of crackers. A pack of dried beef strips. A bottle of iodine. A box of wooden matches. A small coil of wire. A pair of sunglasses. And a half-gallon plastic bottle with a cap for carrying water \
that's bone dry. \
No water. How hard would it have been for them to fill up the bottle? I become aware of the dryness in my throat and mouth, the cracks in my lips. I've been moving all day long. It's been hot and I've sweat a lot. I do this at home, but there are always streams to drink from, or snow to melt if it should come to it. \
As I refill my pack I have an awful thought. The lake. The one I saw while I was waiting for the gong to sound. What if that's the only water source in the arena? That way they'll guarantee drawing us in to fight. The lake is a full day's journey from where I sit now, a much harder journey with nothing to drink. And then, even if I reach it, it's sure to be heavily guarded by some of the Career Tributes. I'm about to panic when I remember the rabbit I startled earlier today. It has to drink, too. I just have to find out where. \
Twilight is closing in and I am ill at ease. The trees are too thin to offer much concealment. The layer of pine needles that muffles my footsteps also makes tracking animals harder when I need their trails to find water. And I'm still heading downhill, deeper and deeper into a \
valley that seems endless. I\'92m hungry, too, but I don\'92t dare break into my precious store of crackers and beef yet. Instead, I take my knife and go to work on a pine tree, cutting away the outer bark and scraping off a large handful of the softer inner bark. I slowly chew the stuff as I walk along. After a week of the finest food in the world, it\'92s a little hard to choke down. But I\'92ve eaten plenty of pine in my life. I\'92ll adjust quickly. \
In another hour, it\'92s clear I\'92ve got to find a place to camp. Night creatures are coming out. I can hear the occasional hoot or howl, my first clue that I\'92ll be competing with natural predators for the rabbits. As to whether I\'92ll be viewed as a source of food, it\'92s too soon to tell. There could be any number of animals stalking me at this moment. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571
\cf0 But right now, I decide to make my fellow tributes a priority. I\'92m sure many will continue hunting through the night. Those who fought it out at the Cornucopia will have food, an abundance of water from the lake, torches or flashlights, and weapons they\'92re itching to use. I can only hope I\'92ve traveled far and fast enough to be out of range. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Before settling down, I take my wire and set two twitch-up snares in the brush. I know it\'92s risky to be setting traps, but food will go so fast out here. And I can\'92t set snares on the run. Still, I walk another five minutes before making camp. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 I pick my tree carefully. A willow, not terribly tall but set in a clump of other willows, offering concealment in those long, flowing tresses. I climb up, sticking to the stronger branches close to the trunk, and find a sturdy fork for my bed. It takes some doing, but I arrange the sleeping bag in a relatively comfortable manner. I place my backpack in the foot of the bag, then slide in after it. As a precaution, I remove my belt, loop it all the way around the branch and my sleeping bag, and refasten it at my waist. Now if I roll over in my sleep, I won\'92t go crashing to the ground. I\'92m small enough to tuck the top of the bag over my head, but I put on my hood as well. As night falls, the air is cooling quickly. Despite the risk I took in getting the backpack, I know now it was the right choice. This sleeping bag, radiating back and preserving my body heat, will be invaluable. I\'92m sure there are several other tributes whose biggest concern right now is how to stay warm whereas I may actually be able to get a few hours of sleep. If only I wasn\'92t so thirsty . . . \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Night has just come when I hear the anthem that proceeds the death recap. Through the branches I can see the seal of the Capitol, which appears to be floating in the sky. I\'92m actually viewing another screen, an enormous one that\'92s transported by of one of their disappearing hovercraft. The anthem fades out and the sky goes dark for a moment. At home, we would be watching full coverage of each and every killing, but that\'92s thought to give an unfair advantage to the living tributes. For instance, if I got my hands on the bow and shot someone, my secret would be revealed to all. No, here in the arena, all we see are the same photographs they showed when they televised our training scores. Simple head shots. But now instead of scores they post only district numbers. I take a deep breath as the face of the eleven dead tributes begin and tick them off one by one on my fingers. \
The first to appear is the girl from District 3. That means that the Career Tributes from 1 and 2 have all survived. No surprise there. Then the boy from 4. I didn\'92t expect that one, usually all the Careers make it through the first day. The boy from District 5 . . . I guess the fox-faced girl made it. Both tributes from 6 and 7. The boy from 8. Both from 9. Yes, there\'92s the boy who I fought for the \
backpack. I\'92ve run through my fingers, only one more dead tribute to go. Is it Peeta? No, there\'92s the girl from District 10. That\'92s it. The Capitol seal is back with a final musical flourish. Then darkness and the sounds of the forest resume. \
I\'92m relieved Peeta\'92s alive. I tell myself again that if I get killed, his winning will benefit my mother and Prim the most. This is what I tell myself to explain the conflicting emotions that arise when I think of Peeta. The gratitude that he gave me an edge by professing his love for me in the interview. The anger at his superiority on the roof. The dread that we may come face-to-face at any moment in this arena. \
Eleven dead, but none from District 12. I try to work out who is left. Five Career Tributes. Foxface. Thresh and Rue. Rue . . . so she made it through the first day after all. I can\'92t help feeling glad. That makes ten of us. The other three I\'92ll figure out tomorrow. Now when it is dark, and I have traveled far, and I am nestled high in this tree, now I must try and rest. \
I haven\'92t really slept in two days, and then there\'92s been the long day\'92s journey into the arena. Slowly, I allow my \
muscles to relax. My eyes to close. The last thing I think is it\'92s lucky I don\'92t snore. . . . \
Snap! The sound of a breaking branch wakes me. How long have I been asleep? Four hours? Five? The tip of my nose is icy cold. Snap! Snap! What\'92s going on? This is not the sound of a branch under someone\'92s foot, but the sharp crack of one coming from a tree. Snap! Snap! I judge it to be several hundred yards to my right. Slowly, noiselessly, I turn myself in that direction. For a few minutes, there\'92s nothing but blackness and some scuffling. Then I see a spark and a small fire begins to bloom. A pair of hands warms over flames, but I can\'92t make out more than that. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 I have to bite my lip not to scream every foul name I know at the fire starter. What are they thinking? A fire just at nightfall would have been one thing. Those who battled at the Cornucopia, with their superior strength and surplus of supplies, they couldn\'92t possibly have been near enough to spot the flames then. But now, when they\'92ve probably been combing the woods for hours looking for victims. You might as well be waving a flag and shouting, \'93Come and get me!\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 And here I am a stone\'92s throw from the biggest idiot in the Games. Strapped in a tree. Not daring to flee since my general location has just been broadcast to any killer who cares. I mean, I know it\'92s cold out here and not everybody has a sleeping bag. But then you grit your teeth and stick it out until dawn! \
I lay smoldering in my bag for the next couple of hours really thinking that if I can get out of this tree, I won\'92t have the least problem taking out my new neighbor. My instinct has been to flee, not fight. But obviously this person\'92s a hazard. Stupid people are dangerous. And this one probably doesn\'92t have much in the way of weapons while I\'92ve got this excellent knife. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 The sky is still dark, but I can feel the first signs of dawn approaching. I\'92m beginning to think we \'97 meaning the person whose death I\'92m now devising and me \'97 we might actually have gone unnoticed. Then I hear it. Several pairs of feet breaking into a run. The fire starter must have dozed off. They\'92re on her before she can escape. I know it\'92s a girl now, I can tell by the pleading, the agonized scream that follows. Then there\'92s laughter and congratulations from several voices. Someone cries out, \'93Twelve down and eleven to go!\'94 which gets a round \
\pard\pardeftab720\sa570
\cf0 of appreciative hoots. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 So they\'92re fighting in a pack. I\'92m not really surprised. Often alliances are formed in the early stages of the Games. The strong band together to hunt down the weak then, when the tension becomes too great, begin to turn on one another. I don\'92t have to wonder too hard who has made this alliance. It\'92ll be the remaining Career Tributes from Districts 1, 2, and 4. Two boys and three girls. The ones who lunched together. \
For a moment, I hear them checking the girl for supplies. I can tell by their comments they\'92ve found nothing good. I wonder if the victim is Rue but quickly dismiss the thought. She\'92s much too bright to be building a fire like that. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 \'93Better clear out so they can get the body before it starts stinking.\'94 I\'92m almost certain that\'92s the brutish boy from District 2. There are murmurs of assent and then, to my horror, I hear the pack heading toward me. They do not know I\'92m here. How could they? And I\'92m well concealed in the clump of trees. At least while the sun stays down. Then my black sleeping bag will turn from camouflage to trouble. If they just keep moving, they will pass me and \
\pard\pardeftab720\sa570
\cf0 be gone in a minute. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 But the Careers stop in the clearing about ten yards from my tree. They have flashlights, torches. I can see an arm here, a boot there, through the breaks in the branches. I turn to stone, not even daring to breathe. Have they spotted me? No, not yet. I can tell from their words their minds are elsewhere. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa82
\cf0 \'93Shouldn\'92t we have heard a cannon by now?\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl1058
\cf0 \'93I\'92d say yes. Nothing to prevent them from going in immediately.\'94 \'93Unless she isn\'92t dead.\'94 \'93She\'92s dead. I stuck her myself.\'94 \'93Then where\'92s the cannon?\'94 \'93Someone should go back. Make sure the job\'92s done.\'94 \'93Yeah, we don\'92t want to have to track her down twice.\'94 \'93I said she\'92s dead!\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa705
\cf0 An argument breaks out until one tribute silences the others. \'93We\'92re wasting time! I\'92ll go finish her and let\'92s move on!\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sa1270\qc
\cf0 I almost fall out of the tree. The voice belongs to Peeta. \
\pard\pardeftab720\qc

\b \cf0 End of Chapter 
\b0 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sa570\qc

\b \cf0 Chapter 12. 
\b0 \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Thank goodness, I had the foresight to belt myself in. I\'92ve rolled sideways off the fork and I\'92m facing the ground, held in place by the belt, one hand, and my feet straddling the pack inside my sleeping bag, braced against the trunk. There must have been some rustling when I tipped sideways, but the Careers have been too caught up in their own argument to catch it. \
\'93Go on, then, Lover Boy,\'94 says the boy from District 2. \'93See for yourself.\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I just get a glimpse of Peeta, lit by a torch, heading back to the girl by the fire. His face is swollen with bruises, there\'92s a bloody bandage on one arm, and from the sound of his gait he\'92s limping somewhat. I remember him shaking him his head, telling me not to go into the fight for the supplies, when all along, all along he\'92d planned to throw himself into the thick of things. Just the opposite of what Haymitch had told him to do. \
Okay, I can stomach that. Seeing all those supplies was tempting. But this . . . this other thing. This teaming up with the Career wolf pack to hunt down the rest of us. No \
one from District 12 would think of doing such a thing! Career tributes are overly vicious, arrogant, better fed, but only because they\'92re the Capitol\'92s lapdogs. \
Universally, solidly hated by all but those from their own districts. I can imagine the things they\'92re saying about him back home now. And Peeta had the gall to talk to me about disgrace? \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Obviously, the noble boy on the rooftop was playing just one more game with me. But this will be his last. I will eagerly watch the night skies for signs of his death, if I don\'92t kill him first myself. \
The Career tributes are silent until he gets out of ear shot, then use hushed voices. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93Why don\'92t we just kill him now and get it over with?\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93Let him tag along. What\'92s the harm? And he\'92s handy with that knife.\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571
\cf0 Is he? That\'92s news. What a lot of interesting things I\'92m learning about my friend Peeta today. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl853\sa285
\cf0 \'93Besides, he\'92s our best chance of finding her.\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl853\sa570
\cf0 It takes me a moment to register that the \'93her\'94 they\'92re referring to is me. \'93Why? You think she bought into that sappy romance \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl1138\sa475
\cf0 stuff?\'94 \'93She might have. Seemed pretty simpleminded to me. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl1043\sa285
\cf0 Every time I think about her spinning around in that dress, I want to puke.\'94 \'93Wish we knew how she got that eleven.\'94 \'93Bet you Lover Boy knows.\'94 The sound of Peeta returning silences them. \'93Was she dead?\'94 asks the boy from District 2. \'93No. But she is now,\'94 says Peeta. Just then, the cannon \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl853
\cf0 fires. \'93Ready to move on?\'94 The Career pack sets off at a run just as dawn begins to break, and birdsong fills the air. I remain in my awkward \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 position, muscles trembling with exertion for a while longer, then hoist myself back onto my branch. I need to get down, to get going, but for a moment I lie there, digesting what I\'92ve heard. Not only is Peeta with the Careers, he\'92s helping them find me. The simpleminded girl who has to be taken seriously because of her eleven. Because she can use a bow and arrow. Which Peeta knows better than anyone. \
But he hasn\'92t told them yet. Is he saving that information because he knows it\'92s all that keeps him alive? Is he still pretending to love me for the audience? What is going on in his head? \
Suddenly, the birds fall silent. Then one gives a high-pitched warning call. A single note. Just like the one Gale and I heard when the redheaded Avox girl was caught. High above the dying campfire a hovercraft materializes. A set of huge metal teeth drops down. Slowly, gently, the dead tribute girl is lifted into the hovercraft. Then it vanishes. The birds resume their song. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93Move,\'94 I whisper to myself. I wriggle out of my sleeping bag, roll it up, and place it in the pack. I take a deep \
breath. While I\'92ve been concealed by darkness and the sleeping bag and the willow branches, it has probably been difficult for the cameras to get a good shot of me. I know they must be tracking me now though. The minute I hit the ground, I\'92m guaranteed a close-up. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 The audience will have been beside themselves, knowing I was in the tree, that I overheard the Careers talking, that I discovered Peeta was with them. Until I work out exactly how I want to play that, I\'92d better at least act on top of things. Not perplexed. Certainly not confused or frightened. \
No, I need to look one step ahead of the game. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 So as I slide out of the foliage and into the dawn light, I pause a second, giving the cameras time to lock on me. Then I cock my head slightly to the side and give a knowing smile. There! Let them figure out what that means! \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 I\'92m about to take off when I think of my snares. Maybe it\'92s imprudent to check them with the others so close. But have to. Too many years of hunting, I guess. And the lure of possible meat. I\'92m rewarded with one fine rabbit. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 In no time, I\'92ve cleaned and gutted the animal, leaving the head, feet, tail, skin, and innards, under a pile of leaves. I\'92m wishing for a fire \'97 eating raw rabbit can give you rabbit fever, a lesson I learned the hard way \'97 when I think of the dead tribute. I hurry back to her camp. Sure enough, the coals of her dying fire are still hot. I cut up the rabbit, fashion a spit out of branches, and set it over the coals. \
I\'92m glad for the cameras now. I want sponsors to see I can hunt, that I\'92m a good bet because I won\'92t be lured into traps as easily as the others will by hunger. While the rabbit cooks, I grind up part of a charred branch and set about camouflaging my orange pack. The black tones it down, but I feel a layer of mud would definitely help. Of course, to have mud, I\'92d need water . . . \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571
\cf0 I pull on my gear, grab my spit, kick some dirt over the coals, and take off in the opposite direction the Careers went. I eat half the rabbit as I go, then wrap up the leftovers in my plastic for later. The meat stops the grumbling in my stomach but does little to quench my thirst. Water is my top priority now. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 As I hike along, I feel certain I\'92m still holding the screen in the Capitol, so I\'92m careful to continue to hide my emotions. But what a good time Claudius Templesmith must be having with his guest commentators, dissecting Peeta\'92s behavior, my reaction. What to make of it all? Has Peeta revealed his true colors? How does this affect the betting odds? Will we lose sponsors? Do we even have sponsors? Yes, I feel certain we do, or at least did. \
Certainly Peeta has thrown a wrench into our star-crossed lover dynamic. Or has he? Maybe, since he hasn\'92t spoken much about me, we can still get some mileage out of it. Maybe people will think it\'92s something we plotted together if I seem like it amuses me now. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 The sun rises in the sky and even through the canopy it seems overly bright. I coat my lips in some grease from the rabbit and try to keep from panting, but it\'92s no use. It\'92s only been a day and I\'92m dehydrating fast. I try and think of everything I know about finding water. It runs downhill, so, in fact, continuing down into this valley isn\'92t a bad thing. If I could just locate a game trail or spot a particularly green patch of vegetation, these might help me along, but nothing seems to change. There\'92s just the slight gradual slope, the birds, the sameness to the trees. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 As the day wears on, I know I\'92m headed for trouble. What little urine I\'92ve been able to pass is a dark brown, my head is aching, and there\'92s a dry patch on my tongue that refuses to moisten. The sun hurts my eyes so I dig out my sunglasses, but when I put them on they do something funny to my vision, so I just stuff them back in my pack. \
It\'92s late afternoon when I think I\'92ve found help. I spot a cluster of berry bushes and hurry to strip the fruit, to suck the sweet juices from the skins. But just as I\'92m holding them to my lips, I get a hard look at them. What I thought were blueberries have a slightly different shape, and when I break one open the insides are bloodred. I don\'92t recognize these berries, perhaps they are edible, but I\'92m guessing this is some evil trick on the part of the Gamemakers. Even the plant instructor in the Training Center made a point of telling us to avoid berries unless you were 100 percent sure they weren\'92t toxic. Something I already knew, but I\'92m so thirsty it takes her reminder to give me the strength to fling them away. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Fatigue is beginning to settle on me, but it\'92s not the usual tiredness that follows a long hike. I have to stop and rest frequently, although I know the only cure for \
what ails me requires continued searching. I try a new tactic \'97 climbing a tree as high as I dare in my shaky state \'97 to look for any signs of water. But as far as I can see in any direction, there\'92s the same unrelenting stretch of forest. \
Determined to go on until nightfall, I walk until I\'92m stumbling over my own feet. \
Exhausted, I haul myself up into a tree and belt myself in. I\'92ve no appetite, but I suck on a rabbit bone just to give my mouth something to do. Night falls, the anthem plays, and high in the sky I see the picture of the girl, who was apparently from District 8. The one Peeta went back to finish off. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 My fear of the Career pack is minor compared to my burning thirst. Besides, they were heading away from me and by now they, too, will have to rest. With the scarcity of water, they may even have had to return to the lake for refills. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa705
\cf0 Maybe, that is the only course for me as well. \
\pard\pardeftab720\qc
\cf0 Morning brings distress. My heads throbs with every beat \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 of my heart. Simple movements send stabs of pain through my joints. I fall, rather than jump from the tree. It takes several minutes for me to assemble my gear. Somewhere inside me, I know this is wrong. I should be acting with more caution, moving with more urgency. But my mind seems foggy and forming a plan is hard. I lean back against the trunk of my tree, one finger gingerly stroking the sandpaper surface of my tongue, as I assess my options. How can I get water? \
Return to the lake. No good. I\'92d never make it. \
Hope for rain. There\'92s not a cloud in the sky. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Keep looking. Yes, this is my only chance. But then, another thought hits me, and the surge of anger that follows brings me to me senses. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 Haymitch! He could send me water! Press a button and have it delivered to me in a silver parachute in minutes. I know I must have sponsors, at least one or two who could afford a pint of liquid for me. Yes, it\'92s pricey, but these people, they\'92re made of money. And they\'92ll be betting on me as well. Perhaps Haymitch doesn\'92t realize how deep my need is. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I say in a voice as loud as I dare. \'93Water.\'94 I wait, hopefully, for a parachute to descend from the sky. But nothing is forthcoming. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 Something is wrong. Am I deluded about having sponsors? Or has Peeta\'92s behavior made them all hang back? No, I don\'92t believe it. There\'92s someone out there who wants to buy me water only Haymitch is refusing to let it go through. As my mentor, he gets to control the flow of gifts from the sponsors. I know he hates me. He\'92s made that clear enough. But enough to let me die? From this? He can\'92t do that, can he? If a mentor mistreats his tributes, he\'92ll be held accountable by the viewers, by the people back in District 12. Even Haymitch wouldn\'92t risk that, would he? Say what you will about my fellow traders in the Hob, but I don\'92t think they\'92d welcome him back there if he let me die this way. And then where would he get his liquor? So . . . what? Is he trying to make me suffer for defying him? Is he directing all the sponsors toward Peeta? Is he just too drunk to even notice what\'92s going on at the moment? Somehow I don\'92t believe that and I don\'92t believe he\'92s trying to kill me off by neglect, either. He has, in fact, in his own unpleasant way, genuinely been trying to prepare me for this. Then what is going on? \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I bury my face in my hands. There\'92s no danger of tears now, I couldn\'92t produce one to save my life. What is Haymitch doing? Despite my anger, hatred, and suspicions, a small voice in the back of my head whispers an answer. \
Maybe he\'92s sending you a message, it says. A message. Saying what? Then I know. There\'92s only one good reason Haymitch could be withholding water from me. Because he knows I\'92ve almost found it. \
I grit my teeth and pull myself to my feet. My backpack seems to have tripled in weight. I find a broken branch that will do for a walking stick and I start off. The sun\'92s beating down, even more searing than the first two days. I feel like an old piece of leather, drying and cracking in the heat. every step is an effort, but I refuse to stop. I refuse to sit down. If I sit, there\'92s a good chance I won\'92t be able to get up again, that I won\'92t even remember my task. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 What easy prey I am! Any tribute, even tiny Rue, could take me right now, merely shove me over and kill me with my own knife, and I\'92d have little strength to resist. But if anyone is in my part of the woods, they ignore me. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 The truth is, I feel a million miles from another living soul. \
Not alone though. No, they\'92ve surely got a camera tracking me now. I think back to the years of watching tributes starve, freeze, bleed, and dehydrate to death. Unless there\'92s a really good fight going on somewhere, I\'92m being featured. \
My thoughts turn to Prim. It\'92s likely she won\'92t be watching me live, but they\'92ll show updates at the school during lunch. For her sake, I try to look as least desperate as I can. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 But by afternoon, I know the end is coming. My legs are shaking and my heart too quick. I keep forgetting, exactly what I\'92m doing. I\'92ve stumbled repeatedly and managed to regain my feet, but when the stick slides out from under me, I finally tumble to the ground unable to get up. I let my eyes close. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I have misjudged Haymitch. He has no intention of helping me at all. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 This is all right, I think. This is not so bad here. The air is \
less hot, signifying evening\'92s approach. There\'92s a slight, sweet scent that reminds me of lilies. My fingers stroke the smooth ground, sliding easily across the top. This is an okay place to die, I think. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 My fingertips make small swirling patterns in the cool, slippery earth. I love mud, I think. How many times I\'92ve tracked game with the help of its soft, readable surface. Good for bee stings, too. Mud. Mud. Mud! My eyes fly open and I dig my fingers into the earth. It is mud! My nose lifts in the air. And those are lilies! Pond lilies! \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I crawl now, through the mud, dragging myself toward the scent. Five yards from where I fell, I crawl through a tangle of plants into a pond. Floating on the top, yellow flowers in bloom, are my beautiful lilies. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 It\'92s all I can do not to plunge my face into the water and gulp down as much as I can hold. But I have jus enough sense left to abstain. With trembling hands, I get out my flask and fill it with water. I add what I remember to be the right number of drops of iodine for purifying it. The half an hour of waiting is agony, but I do it. At least, I think it\'92s a half an hour, but it\'92s certainly as long as I can stand. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Slowly, easy now, I tell myself. I take one swallow and make myself wait. Then another. Over the next couple of hours, I drink the entire half gallon. Then a second. I prepare another before I retire to a tree where I continue sipping, eating rabbit, and even indulge in one of my precious crackers. By the time the anthem plays, I feel remarkably better. There are no faces tonight, no tributes died today. Tomorrow I\'92ll stay here, resting, camouflaging my backpack with mud, catching some of those little fish I saw as I sipped, digging up the roots of the pond lilies to make a nice meal. I snuggle down in my sleeping bag, hanging on to my water bottle for dear life, which, of course, it is. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 A few hours later, the stampede of feet shakes me from slumber. I look around in bewilderment. It\'92s not yet dawn, but my stinging eyes can see it. \
It would be hard to miss the wall of fire descending on me. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\qc

\b \cf0 End of Chapter

\b \cf0 Chapter 13. 
\b0 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 My first impulse is to scramble from the tree, but I\'92m belted in. Somehow my fumbling fingers release the buckle and I fall to the ground in a heap, still snarled in my sleeping bag. There\'92s no time for any kind of packing. Fortunately, my backpack and water bottle are already in the bag. I shove in the belt, hoist the bag over my shoulder, and flee. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 The world has transformed to flame and smoke. Burning branches crack from trees and fall in showers of sparks at my feet. All I can do is follow the others, the rabbits and deer and I even spot a wild dog pack shooting through the woods. I trust their sense of direction because their instincts are sharper than mine. But they are much faster, flying through the underbrush so gracefully as my boots catch on roots and fallen tree limbs, that there\'92s no way I can keep apace with them. \
The heat is horrible, but worse than the heat is the smoke, which threatens to suffocate me at any moment. I pull the top of my shirt up over my nose, grateful to find it soaked in sweat, and it offers a thin veil of protection. And I run, choking, my bag banging against \
my back, my face cut with branches that materialize from the gray haze without warning, because I know I am supposed to run. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 This was no tribute\'92s campfire gone out of control, no accidental occurrence. The flames that bear down on me have an unnatural height, a uniformity that marks them as human-made, machine-made, Gamemaker-made. Things have been too quiet today. No deaths, perhaps no fights at all. The audience in the Capitol will be getting bored, claiming that these Games are verging on dullness. This is the one thing the Games must not do. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 It\'92s not hard to follow the Gamemakers\'92 motivation. There is the Career pack and then there are the rest of us, probably spread far and thin across the arena. This fire is designed to flush us out, to drive us together. It may not be the most original device I\'92ve seen, but it\'92s very, very effective. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571
\cf0 I hurdle over a burning log. Not high enough. The tail end of my jacket catches on fire and I have to stop to rip it from my body and stamp out the flames. But I don\'92t dare leave the jacket, scorched and smoldering as it is, I take the risk of shoving it in my sleeping bag, hoping the \
\pard\pardeftab720\qc
\cf0 lack of air will quell what I haven\'92t extinguished. This is \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 all I have, what I carry on my back, and it\'92s little enough to survive with. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 In a matter of minutes, my throat and nose are burning. The coughing begins soon after and my lungs begin to feel as if they are actually being cooked. Discomfort turns to distress until each breath sends a searing pain through my chest. I manage to take cover under a stone outcropping just as the vomiting begins, and I lose my meager supper and whatever water has remained in my stomach. Crouching on my hands and knees, I retch until there\'92s nothing left to come up. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 I know I need to keep moving, but I\'92m trembling and light-headed now, gasping for air. I allow myself about a spoonful of water to rinse my mouth and spit then take a few swallows from my bottle. You get one minute, I tell myself. One minute to rest. I take the time to reorder my supplies, wad up the sleeping bag, and messily stuff everything into the backpack. My minute\'92s up. I know it\'92s time to move on, but the smoke has clouded my thoughts. The swift-footed animals that were my compass have left me behind. I know I haven\'92t been in this part of the woods before, there were no sizable rocks \
\pard\pardeftab720\qc
\cf0 like the one I\'92m sheltering against on my earlier travels. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Where are the Gamemakers driving me? Back to the lake? To a whole new terrain filled with new dangers? I had just found a few hours of peace at the pond when this attack began. Would there be any way I could travel parallel to the fire and work my way back there, to a source of water at least? The wall of fire must have an end and it won\'92t burn indefinitely. Not because the Gamemakers couldn\'92t keep it fueled but because, again, that would invite accusations of boredom from the audience. If I could get back behind the fire line, I could avoid meeting up with the Careers. I\'92ve just decided to try and loop back around, although it will require miles of travel away from the inferno and then a very circuitous route back, when the first fireball blasts into the rock about two feet from my head. I spring out from under my ledge, energized by renewed fear. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571
\cf0 The game has taken a twist. The fire was just to get us moving, now the audience will get to see some real fun. When I hear the next hiss, I flatten on the ground, not taking time to look. The fireball hits a tree off to my left, engulfing it in flames. To remain still is death. I\'92m barely on my feet before the third ball hits the ground where I was lying, sending a pillar of fire up behind me. Time \
\pard\pardeftab720\qc
\cf0 loses meaning now as I frantically try to dodge the \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 attacks. I can\'92t see where they\'92re being launched from, but it\'92s not a hovercraft. The angles are not extreme enough. Probably this whole segment of the woods has been armed with precision launchers that are concealed in trees or rocks. Somewhere, in a cool and spotless room, a Gamemaker sits at a set of controls, fingers on the triggers that could end my life in a second. All that is needed is a direct hit. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Whatever vague plan I had conceived regarding returning to my pond is wiped from my mind as I zigzag and dive and leap to avoid the fireballs. Each one is only the size of an apple, but packs tremendous power on contact. Every sense I have goes into overdrive as the need to survive takes over. There\'92s no time to judge if a move is the correct one. When there\'92s a hiss, I act or die. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 Something keeps me moving forward, though. A lifetime of watching the Hunger Games lets me know that certain areas of the arena are rigged for certain attacks. And that if I can just get away from this section, I might be able to move out of reach of the launchers. I might also then fall straight into a pit of vipers, but I can\'92t worry about that now. \
\pard\pardeftab720\qc
\cf0 How long I scramble along dodging the fireballs I can\'92t \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 say, but the attacks finally begin to abate. Which is good, because I\'92m retching again. This time it\'92s an acidic substance that scalds my throat and makes its way into my nose as well. I\'92m forced to stop as my body convulses, trying desperately to rid itself of the poisons I\'92ve been sucking in during the attack. I wait for the next hiss, the next signal to bolt. It doesn\'92t come. The force of the retching has squeezed tears out of my stinging eyes. My clothes are drenched in sweat. Somehow, through the smoke and vomit, I pick up the scent of singed hair. My hand fumbles to my braid and finds a fireball has seared off at least six inches of it. Strands of blackened hair crumble in my fingers. I stare at them, fascinated by the transformation, when the hissing registers. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571
\cf0 My muscles react, only not fast enough this time. The fireball crashes into the ground at my side, but not before it skids across my right calf. Seeing my pants leg on fire sends me over the edge. I twist and scuttle backward on my hands and feet, shrieking, trying to remove myself from the horror. When I finally regain enough sense, I roll the leg back and forth on the ground, which stifles the worst of it. But then, without thinking, I rip away the remaining fabric with my bare \
\pard\pardeftab720\sa570
\cf0 hands. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I sit on the ground, a few yards from the blaze set off by the fireball. My calf is screaming, my hands covered in red welts. I\'92m shaking too hard to move. If the Gamemakers want to finish me off, now is the time. \
I hear Cinna\'92s voice, carrying images of rich fabric and sparkling gems. \'93Katniss, the girl who was on fire.\'94 What a good laugh the Gamemakers must be having over that one. Perhaps, Cinna\'92s beautiful costumes have even brought on this particular torture for me. I know he couldn\'92t have foreseen this, must be hurting for me because, in fact, I believe he cares about me. But all in all, maybe showing up stark naked in that chariot would have been safer for me. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 The attack is now over. The Gamemakers don\'92t want me dead. Not yet anyway. Everyone knows they could destroy us all within seconds of the opening gong. The real sport of the Hunger Games is watching the tributes kill one another. Every so often, they do kill a tribute just to remind the players they can. But mostly, they manipulate us into confronting one another face-to-face. Which means, if I am no longer being fired at, there is at \
\pard\pardeftab720\sa570\qc
\cf0 least one other tribute close at hand. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I would drag myself into a tree and take cover now if I could, but the smoke is still thick enough to kill me. I make myself stand and begin to limp away from the wall of flames that lights up the sky. It does not seem to be pursuing me any longer, except with its stinking black clouds. \
Another light, daylight, begins to softly emerge. Swirls of smoke catch the sunbeams. My visibility is poor. I can see maybe fifteen yards in any direction. A tribute could easily be concealed from me here. I should draw my knife as a precaution, but I doubt my ability to hold it for long. The pain in my hands can in no way compete with that in my calf. I hate burns, have always hated them, even a small one gotten from pulling a pan of bread from the oven. It is the worst kind of pain to me, but I have never experienced anything like this. \
I\'92m so weary I don\'92t even notice I\'92m in the pool until I\'92m ankle-deep. It\'92s spring-fed, bubbling up out of a crevice in some rocks, and blissfully cool. I plunge my hands into the shallow water and feel instant relief. Isn\'92t that what my mother always says? The first treatment for a burn is \
cold water? That it draws out the heat? But she means minor burns. Probably she\'92d recommend it for my hands. But what of my calf? Although I have not yet had the courage to examine it, I\'92m guessing that it\'92s an injury in a whole different class. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I lie on my stomach at edge of the pool for a while, dangling my hands in the water, examining the little flames on my fingernails that are beginning to chip off. Good. I\'92ve had enough fire for a lifetime. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I bathe the blood and ash from my face. I try to recall all I know about burns. They are common injuries in the Seam where we cook and heat our homes with coal. Then there are the mine accidents. . . . A family once brought in an unconscious young man pleading with my mother to help him. The district doctor who\'92s responsible for treating the miners had written him off, told the family to take him home to die. But they wouldn\'92t accept this. He lay on our kitchen table, senseless to the world. I got a glimpse of the wound on his thigh, gaping, charred flesh, burned clear down to the bone, before I ran from the house. I went to the woods and hunted the entire day, haunted by the gruesome leg, memories of my father\'92s death. What\'92s funny was, Prim, who\'92s scared of \
her own shadow, stayed and helped. My mother says healers are born, not made. They did their best, but the man died, just like the doctor said he would. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 My leg is in need of attention, but I still can\'92t look at it. What if it\'92s as bad as the man\'92s and I can see my bone? Then I remember my mother saying that if a burn\'92s severe, the victim might not even feel pain because the nerves would be destroyed. Encouraged by this, I sit up and swing my leg in front of me. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 I almost faint at the sight of my calf. The flesh is a brilliant red covered with blisters. I force myself to take deep, slow breaths, feeling quite certain the cameras are on my face. I can\'92t show weakness at this injury. Not if I want help. Pity does not get you aid. Admiration at your refusal to give in does. I cut the remains of the pant leg off at the knee and examine the injury more closely. The burned area is about the size of my hand. None of the skin is blackened. I think it\'92s not too bad to soak. Gingerly I stretch out my leg into the pool, propping the heel of my boot on a rock so the leather doesn\'92t get too sodden, and sigh, because this does offer some relief. I know there are herbs, if I could find them, that would speed the healing, but I can\'92t quite call them to mind. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Water and time will probably be all I have to work with. \
Should I be moving on? The smoke is slowly clearing but still too heavy to be healthy. If I do continue away from the fire, won\'92t I be walking straight into the weapons of the Careers? Besides, every time I lift my leg from the water, the pain rebounds so intensely I have to slide it back in. My hands are slightly less demanding. They can handle small breaks from the pool. So I slowly put my gear back in order. First I fill my bottle with the pool water, treat it, and when enough time has passed, begin to rehydrate my body. After a time, I force myself to nibble on a cracker, which helps settle my stomach. I roll up my sleeping bag. Except for a few black marks, it\'92s relatively unscathed. My jacket\'92s another matter. Stinking and scorched, at least a foot of the back beyond repair. I cut off the damaged area leaving me with a garment that comes just to the bottom of my ribs. But the hood\'92s intact and it\'92s far better than nothing. \
Despite the pain, drowsiness begins to take over. I\'92d take to a tree and try to rest, except I\'92d be too easy to spot. Besides, abandoning my pool seems impossible. I neatly arrange my supplies, even settle my pack on my shoulders, but I can\'92t seem to leave. I spot some water \
plants with edible roots and make a small meal with my last piece of rabbit. Sip water. Watch the sun make its slow arc across the sky. Where would I go anyway that is any safer than here? I lean back on my pack, overcome by drowsiness. If the Careers want me, let them find me, I think before drifting into a stupor. Let them find me. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 And find me, they do. It\'92s lucky I\'92m ready to move on because when I hear the feet, I have less than a minute head start. Evening has begun to fall. The moment I awake, I\'92m up and running, splashing across the pool, flying into the underbrush. My leg slows me down, but I sense my pursuers are not as speedy as they were before the fire, either. I hear their coughs, their raspy voices calling to one another. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 Still, they are closing in, just like a pack of wild dogs, and so I do what I have done my whole life in such circumstances. I pick a high tree and begin to climb. If running hurt, climbing is agonizing because it requires not only exertion but direct contact of my hands on the tree bark. I\'92m fast, though, and by the time they\'92ve reached the base of my trunk, I\'92m twenty feet up. For a moment, we stop and survey one another. I hope they can\'92t hear the pounding of my heart. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 This could be it, I think. What chance do I have against them? All six are there, the five Careers and Peeta, and my only consolation is they\'92re pretty beat-up, too. Even so, look at their weapons. Look at their faces, grinning and snarling at me, a sure kill above them. It seems pretty hopeless. But then something else registers. They\'92re bigger and stronger than I am, no doubt, but they\'92re also heavier. There\'92s a reason it\'92s me and not Gale who ventures up to pluck the highest fruit, or rob the most remote bird nests. I must weigh at least fifty or sixty pounds less than the smallest Career. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Now I smile. \'93How\'92s everything with you?\'94 I call down cheerfully. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 This takes them aback, but I know the crowd will love it. \
\'93Well enough,\'94 says the boy from District 2. \'93Yourself?\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93It\'92s been a bit warm for my taste,\'94 I say. I can almost hear the laughter from the Capitol. \'93The air\'92s better up here. Why don\'92t you come on up?\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 \'93Think I will,\'94 says the same boy. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93Here, take this, Cato,\'94 says the girl from District 1, and she offers him the silver bow and sheath of arrows. My bow! My arrows! Just the sight of them makes me so angry I want to scream, at myself, at that traitor Peeta for distracting me from having them. I try to make eye contact with him now, but he seems to be intentionally avoiding my gaze as he polishes his knife with the edge of his shirt. \
\'93No,\'94 says Cato, pushing away the bow. \'93I\'92ll do better with my sword.\'94 I can see the weapon, a short, heavy blade at his belt. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I give Cato time to hoist himself into the tree before I begin to climb again. Gale always says I remind him of a squirrel the way I can scurry up even the slenderest limb. Part of it\'92s my weight, but part of it\'92s practice. You have to know where to place your hands and feet. I\'92m another thirty feet in the air when I hear the crack and look down to see Cato flailing as he and a branch go down. He hits the ground hard and I\'92m hoping he possibly broke his neck when he gets back to his feet, swearing like a fiend. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 The girl with the arrows, Glimmer I hear someone call her \'97 ugh, the names the people in District 1 give their \
children are so ridiculous \'97 anyway Glimmer scales the tree until the branches begin to crack under her feet and then has the good sense to stop. I\'92m at least eighty feet high now. She tries to shoot me and it\'92s immediately evident that she\'92s incompetent with a bow. One of the arrows gets lodged in the tree near me though and I\'92m able to seize it. I wave it teasingly above her head, as if this was the sole purpose of retrieving it, when actually I mean to use it if I ever get the chance. I could kill them, everyone of them, if those silver weapons were in my hands. The Careers regroup on the ground and I can hear them growling conspiratorially among themselves, furious I have made them look foolish. But twilight has arrived and their window of attack on me is closing. Finally, I hear Peeta say harshly, \'93Oh, let her stay up there. It\'92s not like she\'92s going anywhere. We\'92ll deal with her in the morning.\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Well, he\'92s right about one thing. I\'92m going nowhere. All the relief from the pool water has gone, leaving me to feel the full potency of my burns. I scoot down to a fork in the tree and clumsily prepare for bed. Put on my jacket. Lay out my sleeping bed. Belt myself in and try to keep from moaning. The heat of the bag\'92s too much for \
my leg. I cut a slash in the fabric and hang my calf out in the open air. I drizzle water on the wound, my hands. \
All my bravado is gone. I\'92m weak from pain and hunger but can\'92t bring myself to eat. Even if I can last the night, what will the morning bring? I stare into the foliage trying to will myself to rest, but the burns forbid it. Birds are settling down for the night, singing lullabies to their young. Night creatures emerge. An owl hoots. The faint scent of a skunk cuts through the smoke. The eyes of some animal peer at me from the neighboring tree \'97 a possum maybe \'97 catching the firelight from the Careers\'92 torches. Suddenly, I\'92m up on one elbow. Those are no possum\'92s eyes, I know their glassy reflection too well. In fact, those are not animal eyes at all. In the last dim rays of light, I make her out, watching me silently from between the branches. Rue. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 How long has she been here? The whole time probably. Still and unobserved as the action unfolded beneath her. Perhaps she headed up her tree shortly before I did, hearing the pack was so close. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571
\cf0 For a while we hold each other\'92s gaze. Then, without even rustling a leaf, her little hand slides into the open \
\pard\pardeftab720\sa705\qc
\cf0 and points to something above my head. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394

\b \cf0 Chapter 14. 
\b0 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 My eyes follow the line of her finger up into the foliage above me. At first, I have no idea what she\'92s pointing to, but then, about fifteen feet up, I make out the vague shape in the dimming light. But of . . . of what? Some sort of animal? It looks about the size of a raccoon, but it hangs from the bottom of a branch, swaying ever so slightly. There\'92s something else. Among the familiar evening sounds of the woods, my ears register a low hum. Then I know. It\'92s a wasp nest. \
Fear shoots through me, but I have enough sense to keep still. After all, I don\'92t know what kind of wasp lives there. It could be the ordinary leave-us-alone-and-we\'92ll-leave-youalone type. But these are the Hunger Games, and ordinary isn\'92t the norm. More likely they will be one of the Capitol\'92s muttations, tracker jackers. Like the jabberjays, these killer wasps were spawned in a lab and strategically placed, like land mines, around the districts during the war. Larger than regular wasps, they have a distinctive solid gold body and a sting that raises a lump the size of a plum on contact. Most people can\'92t tolerate more than a few stings. Some die at once. If you live, the hallucinations \
brought on by the venom have actually driven people to madness. And there\'92s another thing, these wasps will hunt down anyone who disturbs their nest and attempt to kill them. That\'92s where the tracker part of the name comes from. \
After the war, the Capitol destroyed all the nests surrounding their city, but the ones near the districts were left untouched. Another reminder of our weakness, I suppose, just like the Hunger Games. Another reason to keep inside the fence of District 12. When Gale and I come across a tracker jacker nest, we immediately head in the opposite direction. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 So is that what hangs above me? I look back to Rue for help, but she\'92s melted into her tree. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 Given my circumstances, I guess it doesn\'92t matter what type of wasp nest it is. I\'92m wounded and trapped. Darkness has given me a brief reprieve, but by the time the sun rises, the Careers will have formulated a plan to kill me. There\'92s no way they could do otherwise after I\'92ve made them look so stupid. That nest may be the sole option I have left. If I can drop it down on them, I may be able to escape. But I\'92ll risk my life in the process. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Of course, I\'92ll never be able to get in close enough to the actual nest to cut it free. I\'92ll have to saw off the branch at the trunk and send the whole thing down. The serrated portion of my knife should be able to manage that. But can my hands? And will the vibration from the sawing raise the swarm? And what if the Careers figure out what I\'92m doing and move their camp? That would defeat the whole purpose. \
I realize that the best chance I\'92ll have to do the sawing without drawing notice will be during the anthem. That could begin any time. I drag myself out of my bag, make sure my knife is secured in my belt, and begin to make my way up the tree. This in itself is dangerous since the branches are becoming precariously thin even for me, but I persevere. When I reach the limb that supports the nest, the humming becomes more distinctive. But it\'92s still oddly subdued if these are tracker jackers. It\'92s the smoke, I think. It\'92s sedated them. This was the one defense the rebels found to battle the wasps. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 The seal of the Capitol shines above me and the anthem blares out. It\'92s now or never, I think, and begin to saw. Blisters burst on my right hand as I awkwardly drag the knife back and forth. Once I\'92ve got a groove, the work \
requires less effort but is almost more than I can handle. I grit my teeth and saw away occasionally glancing at the sky to register that there were no deaths today. That\'92s all right. The audience will be sated seeing me injured and treed and the pack below me. But the anthem\'92s running out and I\'92m only three quarters of the way through the wood when the music ends, the sky goes dark, and I\'92m forced to stop. \
Now what? I could probably finish off the job by sense of feel but that may not be the smartest plan. If the wasps are too groggy, if the nest catches on its way down, if I try to escape, this could all be a deadly waste of time. Better, I think, to sneak up here at dawn and send the nest into my enemies. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 In the faint light of the Careers\'92 torches, I inch back down to my fork to find the best surprise I\'92ve ever had. Sitting on my sleeping bag is a small plastic pot attached to a silver parachute. My first gift from a sponsor! Haymitch must have had it sent in during the anthem. The pot easily fits in the palm of my hand. What can it be? Not food surely. I unscrew the lid and I know by the scent that it\'92s medicine. Cautiously, I probe the surface of the ointment. The \
throbbing in my fingertip vanishes. \
\'93Oh, Haymitch,\'94 I whisper. \'93Thank you.\'94 He has not abandoned me. Not left me to fend entirely for myself. The cost of this medicine must be astronomical. Probably not one but many sponsors have contributed to buy this one tiny pot. To me, it is priceless. \
I dip two fingers in the jar and gently spread the balm over my calf. The effect is almost magical, erasing the pain on contact, leaving a pleasant cooling sensation behind. This is no herbal concoction that my mother grinds up out of woodland plants, it\'92s high-tech medicine brewed up in the Capitol\'92s labs. When my calf is treated, I rub a thin layer into my hands. After wrapping the pot in the parachute, I nestle it safely away in my pack. Now that the pain has eased, it\'92s all I can do to reposition myself in my bag before I plunge into sleep. \
A bird perched just a few feet from me alerts me that a new day is dawning. In the gray morning light, I examine my hands. The medicine has transformed all the angry red patches to a soft baby-skin pink. My leg still feels inflamed, but that burn was far deeper. I apply another coat of medicine and quietly pack up my gear. Whatever \
happens, I\'92m going to have to move and move fast. I also make myself eat a cracker and a strip of beef and drink a few cups of water. \
Almost nothing stayed in my stomach yesterday, and I\'92m already starting to feel the effects of hunger. \
Below me, I can see the Career pack and Peeta asleep on the ground. By her position, leaning up against the trunk of the tree, I\'92d guess Glimmer was supposed to be on guard, but fatigue overcame her. \
My eyes squint as they try to penetrate the tree next to me, but I can\'92t make out Rue. Since she tipped me off, it only seems fair to warn her. Besides, if I\'92m going to die today, it\'92s Rue I want to win. Even if it means a little extra food for my family, the idea of Peeta being crowned victor is unbearable. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I call Rue\'92s name in a hushed whisper and the eyes appear, wide and alert, at once. She points up to the nest again. I hold up my knife and make a sawing motion. She nods and disappears. There\'92s a rustling in a nearby tree. Then the same noise again a bit farther off. I realize she\'92s leaping from tree to tree. It\'92s all I can do \
not to laugh out loud. Is this what she showed the Gamemakers? I imagine her flying around the training equipment never touching the floor. She should have gotten at least a ten. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Rosy streaks are breaking through in the east. I can\'92t afford to wait any longer. Compared to the agony of last night\'92s climb, this one is a cinch. At the tree limb that holds the nest, I position the knife in the groove and I\'92m about to draw the teeth across the wood when I see something moving. There, on the nest. The bright gold gleam of a tracker jacker lazily making its way across the papery gray surface. No question, it\'92s acting a little subdued, but the wasp is up and moving and that means the others will be out soon as well. Sweat breaks out on the palms of my hands, beading up through the ointment, and I do my best to pat them dry on my shirt. If I don\'92t get through this branch in a matter of seconds, the entire swarm could emerge and attack me. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 There\'92s no sense in putting it off. I take a deep breath, grip the knife handle and bear down as hard as I can. Back, forth, back, forth! The tracker jackers begin to buzz and I hear them coming out. Back, forth, back, forth! A stabbing pain shoots through my knee and I \
know one has found me and the others will be honing in. Back, forth, back, forth. And just as the knife cuts through, I shove the end of the branch as far away from me as I can. It crashes down through the lower branches, snagging temporarily on a few but then twisting free until it smashes with a thud on the ground. The nest bursts open like an egg, and a furious swarm of tracker jackers takes to the air. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I feel a second sting on the cheek, a third on my neck, and their venom almost immediately makes me woozy. I cling to the tree with one arm while I rip the barbed stingers out of my flesh. Fortunately, only these three tracker jackers had identified me before the nest went down. The rest of the insects have targeted their enemies on the ground. \
It\'92s mayhem. The Careers have woken to a full-scale tracker jacker attack. Peeta and a few others have the sense to drop everything and bolt. I can hear cries of \'93To the lake! To the lake!\'94 and know they hope to evade the wasps by taking to the water. It must be close if they think they can outdistance the furious insects. Glimmer and another girl, the one from District 4, are not so lucky. They receive multiple stings before they\'92re even \
out of my view. Glimmer appears to go completely mad, shrieking and trying to bat the wasps off with her bow, which is pointless. She calls to the others for help but, of course, no one returns. The girl from District 4 staggers out of sight, although I wouldn\'92t bet on her making it to the lake. I watch Glimmer fall, twitch hysterically around on the ground for a few minutes, and then go still. \
The nest is nothing but an empty shell. The wasps have vanished in pursuit of the others. I don\'92t think they\'92ll return, but I don\'92t want to risk it. I scamper down the tree and hit the ground running in the opposite direction of the lake. The poison from the stingers makes me wobbly, but I find my way back to my own little pool and submerge myself in the water, just in case any wasps are still on my trail. After about five minutes, I drag myself onto the rocks. People have not exaggerated the effects of the tracker jacker stings. Actually, the one on my knee is closer to an orange than a plum in size. A foul-smelling green liquid oozes from the places where I pulled out the stingers. \
The swelling. The pain. The ooze. Watching Glimmer twitching to death on the ground. It\'92s a lot to handle before the sun has even cleared the horizon. I don\'92t want \
to think about what Glimmer must look like now. Her body disfigured. Her swollen fingers stiffening around the bow . . . \
The bow! Somewhere in my befuddled mind one thought connects to another and I\'92m on my feet, teetering through the trees back to Glimmer. The bow. The arrows. I must get them. I haven\'92t heard the cannons fire yet, so perhaps Glimmer is in some sort of coma, her heart still struggling against the wasp venom. But once it stops and the cannon signals her death, a hovercraft will move in and retrieve her body, taking the only bow and sheath of arrows I\'92ve seen out of the Games for good. And I refuse to let them slip through my fingers again! \
I reach Glimmer just as the cannon fires. The tracker jackers have vanished. This girl, so breathtakingly beautiful in her golden dress the night of the interviews, is unrecognizable. Her features eradicated, her limbs three times their normal size. The stinger lumps have begun to explode, spewing putrid green liquid around her. I have to break several of what used to be her fingers with a stone to free the bow. The sheath of arrows is pinned under her back. I try to roll over her body by pulling on one arm, but the flesh disintegrates in \
my hands and I fall back on the ground. \
Is this real? Or have the hallucinations begun? I squeeze my eyes tight and try to breathe through my mouth, ordering myself not to become sick. Breakfast must stay down, it might be days before I can hunt again. A second cannon fires and I\'92m guessing the girl from District 4 has just died. I hear the birds fall silent and then one give the warning call, which means a hovercraft is about to appear. Confused, I think it\'92s for Glimmer, although this doesn\'92t quite make sense because I\'92m still in the picture, still fighting for the arrows. I lurch back onto my knees and the trees around me begin to spin in circles. In the middle of the sky, I spot the hovercraft. I throw myself over Glimmer\'92s body as if to protect it but then I see the girl from District 4 being lifted into the air and vanishing. \
\'93Do this!\'94 I command myself. Clenching my jaw, I dig my hands under Glimmer\'92s body, get a hold on what must be her rib cage, and force her onto her stomach. I can\'92t help it, I\'92m hyperventilating now, the whole thing is so nightmarish and I\'92m losing my grasp on what\'92s real. I tug on the silver sheath of arrows, but it\'92s caught on something, her shoulder blade, something, and finally yank it free. I\'92ve just encircled the sheath with my arms \
when I hear the footsteps, several pairs, coming through the underbrush, and I realize the Careers have come back. They\'92ve come back to kill me or get their weapons or both. \
But it\'92s too late to run. I pull a slimy arrow from the sheath and try to position it on the bowstring but instead of one string I see three and the stench from the stings is so repulsive I can\'92t do it. I can\'92t do it. I can\'92t do it. \
I\'92m helpless as the first hunter crashes through the trees, spear lifted, poised to throw. The shock on Peeta\'92s face makes no sense to me. I wait for the blow. Instead his arm drops to his side. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93What are you still doing here?\'94 he hisses at me. I stare uncomprehendingly as a trickle of water drips off a sting under his ear. His whole body starts sparkling as if he\'92s been dipped in dew. \'93Are you mad?\'94 He\'92s prodding me with the shaft of the spear now. \'93Get up! Get up!\'94 I rise, but he\'92s still pushing at me. What? What is going on? He shoves me away from him hard. \'93Run!\'94 he screams. \'93Run!\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Behind him, Cato slashes his way through the brush. He\'92s \
sparkling wet, too, and badly stung under one eye. I catch the gleam of sunlight on his sword and do as Peeta says. Holding tightly to my bow and arrows, banging into trees that appear out of nowhere, tripping and falling as I try to keep my balance. Back past my pool and into unfamiliar woods. The world begins to bend in alarming ways. A butterfly balloons to the size of a house then shatters into a million stars. Trees transform to blood and splash down over my boots. Ants begin to crawl out of the blisters on my hands and I can\'92t shake them free. They\'92re climbing up my arms, my neck. Someone\'92s screaming, a long high pitched scream that never breaks for breath. I have a vague idea it might be me. I trip and fall into a small pit lined with tiny orange bubbles that hum like the tracker jacker nest. Tucking my knees up to my chin, I wait for death. \
Sick and disoriented, I\'92m able to form only one thought: \
Peeta Mellark just saved my life. \
Then the ants bore into my eyes and I black out. \
