\b \cf0 Chapter 15. 
\b0 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I enter a nightmare from which I wake repeatedly only to find a greater terror awaiting me. All the things I dread most, all the things I dread for others manifest in such vivid detail I can\'92t help but believe they\'92re real. Each time I wake, I think, At last, this is over, but it isn\'92t. It\'92s only the beginning of a new chapter of torture. How many ways do I watch Prim die? Relive my father\'92s last moments? Feel my own body ripped apart? This is the nature of the tracker jacker venom, so carefully created to target the place where fear lives in your brain. \
When I finally do come to my senses, I lie still, waiting for the next onslaught of imagery. But eventually I accept that the poison must have finally worked its way out of my system, leaving my body wracked and feeble. I\'92m still lying on my side, locked in the fetal position. I lift a hand to my eyes to find them sound, untouched by ants that never existed. Simply stretching out my limbs requires an enormous effort. So many parts of me hurt, it doesn\'92t seem worthwhile taking inventory of them. Very, very slowly I manage to sit up. I\'92m in a shallow hole, not filled with the humming orange bubbles of my hallucination but with old, dead leaves. My clothing\'92s \
damp, but I don\'92t know whether pond water, dew, rain, or sweat is the cause. For a long time, all I can do is take tiny sips from my bottle and watch a beetle crawl up the side of a honeysuckle bush. \
How long have I been out? It was morning when I lost reason. Now it\'92s afternoon. But the stiffness in my joints suggests more than a day has passed, even two possibly. If so, I\'92ll have no way of knowing which tributes survived that tracker jacker attack. Not Glimmer or the girl from District 4. But there was the boy from District 1, both tributes from District 2, and Peeta. Did they die from the stings? Certainly if they lived, their last days must have been as horrid as my own. And what about Rue? She\'92s so small, it wouldn\'92t take much venom to do her in. But then again . . . the tracker jackers would\'92ve had to catch her, and she had a good head start. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 A foul, rotten taste pervades my mouth, and the water has little effect on it. I drag myself over to the honeysuckle bush and pluck a flower. I gently pull the stamen through the blossom and set the drop of nectar on my tongue. The sweetness spreads through my mouth, down my throat, warming my veins with memories of summer, and my home woods and Gale\'92s \
presence beside me. For some reason, our discussion from that last morning comes back to me. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93We could do it, you know.\'94 \
\'93What?\'94 \
\'93Leave the district. Run off. Live in the woods. You and I, we could make it.\'94 \
And suddenly, I\'92m not thinking of Gale but of Peeta and . . . Peeta! He saved my life! I think. Because by the time we met up, I couldn\'92t tell what was real and what the tracker jacker venom had caused me to imagine. But if he did, and my instincts tell me he did, what for? Is he simply working the Lover Boy angle he initiated at the interview? Or was he actually trying to protect me? And if he was, what was he doing with those Careers in the first place? None of it makes sense. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571
\cf0 I wonder what Gale made of the incident for a moment and then I push the whole thing out of my mind because for some reason Gale and Peeta do not coexist well together in my thoughts. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 So I focus on the one really good thing that\'92s happened since I landed in the arena. I have a bow and arrows! A full dozen arrows if you count the one I retrieved in the tree. They bear no trace of the noxious green slime that came from Glimmer\'92s body \'97 which leads me to believe that might not have been wholly real \'97 but they have a fair amount of dried blood on them. I can clean them later, but I do take a minute to shoot a few into a nearby tree. They are more like the weapons in the Training Center than my ones at home, but who cares? That I can work with. \
The weapons give me an entirely new perspective on the Games. I know I have tough opponents left to face. But I am no longer merely prey that runs and hides or takes desperate measures. If Cato broke through the trees right now, I wouldn\'92t flee, I\'92d shoot. I find I\'92m actually anticipating the moment with pleasure. \
But first, I have to get some strength back in my body. I\'92m very dehydrated again and my water supply is dangerously low. The little padding I was able to put on by gorging myself during prep time in the Capitol is gone, plus several more pounds as well. My hip bones and ribs are more prominent than I remember them being since \
those awful months after my father\'92s death. And then there are my wounds to contend with \'97 burns, cuts, and bruises from smashing into the trees, and three tracker jacker stings, which are as sore and swollen as ever. I treat my burns with the ointment and try dabbing a bit on my stings as well, but it has no effect on them. My mother knew a treatment for them, some type of leaf that could draw out the poison, but she seldom had cause to use it, and I don\'92t even remember its name let alone its appearance. \
Water first, I think. You can hunt along the way now. It\'92s easy to see the direction I came from by the path of destruction my crazed body made through the foliage. So I walk off in the other direction, hoping my enemies still lie locked in the surreal world of tracker jacker venom. \
I can\'92t move too quickly, my joints reject any abrupt motions. But I establish the slow hunter\'92s tread I use when tracking game. Within a few minutes, I spot a rabbit and make my first kill with the bow and arrow. It\'92s not my usual clean shot through the eye, but I\'92ll take it. After about an hour, I find a stream, shallow but wide, and more than sufficient for my needs. The sun\'92s hot and severe, so while I wait for my water to purify I strip down \
to my underclothes and wade into the mild current. I\'92m filthy from head to toe, I try splashing myself but eventually just lay down in the water for a few minutes, letting it wash off the soot and blood and skin that has started to peel off my burns. After rinsing out my clothes and hanging them on bushes to dry, I sit on the bank in the sun for a bit, untangling my hair with my fingers. My appetite returns and I eat a cracker and a strip of beef. With a handful of moss, I polish the blood from my silver weapons. \
Refreshed, I treat my burns again, braid back my hair, and dress in the damp clothes, knowing the sun will dry them soon enough. Following the stream against its current seems the smartest course of action. I\'92m traveling uphill now, which I prefer, with a source of fresh water not only for myself but possible game. I easily take out a strange bird that must be some form of wild turkey. Anyway, it looks plenty edible to me. By late afternoon, I decide to build a small fire to cook the meat, betting that dusk will help conceal the smoke and I can quench the fire by nightfall. I clean the game, taking extra care with the bird, but there\'92s nothing alarming about it. Once the feathers are plucked, it\'92s no bigger than a chicken, but it\'92s plump and firm. I\'92ve just placed \
the first lot over the coals when I hear the twig snap. \
In one motion, I turn to the sound, bringing the bow and arrow to my shoulder. There\'92s no one there. No one I can see anyway. Then I spot the tip of a child\'92s boot just peeking out from behind the trunk of a tree. My shoulders relax and I grin. She can move through the woods like a shadow, you have to give her that. How else could she have followed me? The words come out of my mouth before I can stop them. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93You know, they\'92re not the only ones who can form alliances,\'94 I say. \
For a moment, no response. Then one of Rue\'92s eyes edges around the trunk. \'93You want me for an ally?\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa705
\cf0 \'93Why not? You saved me with those tracker jackers. You\'92re smart enough to still be alive. And I can\'92t seem to shake you anyway,\'94 I say. She blinks at me, trying to decide. \'93You hungry?\'94 I can see her swallow hard, her eye flickering to the meat. \'93Come on then, I\'92ve had two kills today.\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\qc
\cf0 Rue tentatively steps out into the open. \'93I can fix your \
\pard\pardeftab720\sa705
\cf0 stings.\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sa570
\cf0 \'93Can you?\'94 I ask. \'93How?\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 She digs in the pack she carries and pulls out a handful of leaves. I\'92m almost certain they\'92re the ones my mother uses. \'93Where\'92d you find those?\'94 \
\'93Just around. We all carry them when we work in the orchards. They left a lot of nests there,\'94 says Rue. \'93There are a lot here, too.\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570

\pard\pardeftab720\sl571

\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Hearing this makes me feel like District 12 is some sort of safe haven. I give Rue some matches and she makes sure I have plenty of leaves in case my stings flare up again. We extinguish our fire and head upstream until it\'92s almost nightfall. \

\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa705

\b \cf0 Chapter 16. 
\b0 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Rue has decided to trust me wholeheartedly. I know this because as soon as the anthem finishes she snuggles up against me and falls asleep. Nor do I have any misgivings about her, as I take no particular precautions. If she\'92d wanted me dead, all she would have had to do was disappear from that tree without pointing out the tracker jacker nest. Needling me, at the very back of my mind, is the obvious. Both of us can\'92t win these Games. But since the odds are still against either of us surviving, I manage to ignore the thought. \
Besides, I\'92m distracted by my latest idea about the Careers and their supplies. Somehow Rue and I must find a way to destroy their food. I\'92m pretty sure feeding themselves will be a tremendous struggle. Traditionally, the Career tributes\'92 strategy is to get hold of all the food early on and work from there. The years when they have not protected it well \'97 one year a pack of hideous reptiles destroyed it, another a Gamemakers\'92 flood washed it away \'97 those are usually the years that tributes from other districts have won. That the Careers have been better red growing up is actually to their disadvantage, because they don\'92t know how to be \
hungry. Not the way Rue and I do. \
But I\'92m too exhausted to begin any detailed plan tonight. My wounds recovering, my mind still a bit foggy from the venom, and the warmth of Rue at my side, her head cradled on my shoulder, have given me a sense of security. I realize, for the first time, how very lonely I\'92ve been in the arena. How comforting the presence of another human being can be. I give in to my drowsiness, resolving that tomorrow the tables will turn. Tomorrow, it\'92s the Careers who will have to watch their backs. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 The boom of the cannon jolts me awake. The sky\'92s streaked with light, the birds already chattering. Rue perches in a branch across from me, her hands cupping something. We wait, listening for more shots, but there aren\'92t any. \
\'93Who do you think that was?\'94 I can\'92t help thinking of Peeta. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa705
\cf0 \'93I don\'92t know. It could have been any of the others,\'94 says Rue. \'93I guess we\'92ll know tonight.\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720

\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570

\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570

\'93Breakfast,\'94 says Rue. She holds them out revealing two big eggs. \
\'93What kind are those?\'94 I ask. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570

\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 It\'92d be nice to cook them, but neither of us wants to risk a fire. My guess is the tribute who died today was a \

\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570

another tribute, the boy from District 3, to watch over the supplies. \

For a while, we dig roots, we gather berries and greens, we devise a strategy in hushed voices. And I come to know Rue, the oldest of six kids, fiercely protective of her siblings, who gives her rations to the younger ones, who forages in the meadows in a district where the Peacekeepers are far less obliging than ours. Rue, who when you ask her what she loves most in the world, replies, of all things, \'93Music.\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93Music?\'94 I say. In our world, I rank music somewhere between hair ribbons and rainbows in terms of usefulness. At least a rainbow gives you a tip about the weather. \'93You have a lot of time for that?\'94 \

\cf0 \'93We sing at home. At work, too. That\'92s why I love your pin,\'94 she says, pointing to the mockingjay that I\'92ve again forgotten about. \

That\'92s how everyone knows to knock off,\'94 she continues. \'93They can be dangerous though, if you get too near their nests. But you can\'92t blame them for that.\'94 \

\cf0 I unclasp the pin and hold it out to her. \'93Here, you take it. It has more meaning for you than me.\'94 \

\cf0 \'93Oh, no,\'94 says Rue, closing my fingers back over the pin. \'93I like to see it on you. That\'92s how I decided I could trust you. Or maybe it\'92s a flower. \'93It\'92s a good luck charm.\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\qc
\cf0 \'93Well, it\'92s worked so far,\'94 I say, pinning the mockingjay \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 back on my shirt. \'93Maybe you should just stick with that.\'94 \

We decide to meet afterward at the site where we ate our first meal together. The stream should help guide me back to it. Before I leave, I make sure Rue\'92s well stocked with food and matches. I even insist she take my sleeping bag, in case it\'92s not possible to rendezvous by nightfall. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93What about you? Won\'92t you be cold?\'94 she asks. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93Not if I pick up another bag down by the lake,\'94 I say. \'93You know, stealing isn\'92t illegal here,\'94 I say with a grin. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa705
\cf0 At the last minute, Rue decides to teach me her mockingjay signal, the one she gives to indicate the day\'92s work is done. \'93It might not work. But if you hear the mockingjays singing it, you\'92ll know I\'92m okay, only I can\'92t get back right away.\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\qc
\cf0 \'93Are there many mockingjays here?\'94 I ask. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93Haven\'92t you seen them? They\'92ve got nests everywhere,\'94 she says. I have to admit I haven\'92t noticed. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93Okay, then. If all goes according to plan, I\'92ll see you for dinner,\'94 I say. \
Unexpectedly, Rue throws her arms around me. I only hesitate a moment before I hug her back. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93You be careful,\'94 she says to me. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93You, too,\'94 I say. I turn and head back to the stream, feeling somehow worried. About Rue being killed, about Rue not being killed and the two of us being left for last, about leaving Rue alone, about leaving Prim alone back home. No, Prim has my mother and Gale and a baker who has promised she won\'92t go hungry. Rue has only me. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Once I reach the stream, I have only to follow it downhill to the place I initially picked it up after the tracker jacker attack. I have to be cautious as I move along the water though, because I find my thoughts preoccupied with unanswered questions, most of which concern Peeta. The cannon that fired early this morning, did that signify his \
death? If so, how did he die? At the hand of a Career? And was that in revenge for letting me live? I struggle again to remember that moment over Glimmer\'92s body, when he burst through the trees. But just the fact that he was sparkling leads me to doubt everything that happened. \
I must have been moving very slowly yesterday because I reach the shallow stretch where I took my bath in just a few hours. I stop to replenish my water and add a layer of mud to my backpack. It seems bent on reverting to orange no matter how many times I cover it. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa705
\cf0 My proximity to the Careers\'92 camp sharpens my senses, and the closer I get to them, the more guarded I am, pausing frequently to listen for unnatural sounds, an arrow already fitted into the string of my bow. I don\'92t see any other tributes, but I do notice some of the things Rue has mentioned. Patches of the sweet berries. A bush with the leaves that healed my stings. Clusters of tracker jacker nests in the vicinity of the tree I was trapped in. And here and there, the black-and-white flash of a mockingjay wing in the branches high over my head. \
\pard\pardeftab720\qc
\cf0 When I reach the tree with the abandoned nest at the \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 foot, I pause a moment, to gather my courage. Rue has given specific instructions on how to reach the best spying place near the lake from this point. Remember, I tell myself. You\'92re the hunter now, not them. I get a firmer grasp on my bow and go on. I make it to the copse Rue has told me about and again have to admire her cleverness. It\'92s right at the edge of the wood, but the bushy foliage is so thick down low I can easily observe the Career camp without being spotted. Between us lies the flat expanse where the Games began. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 There are four tributes. The boy from District 1, Cato and the girl from District 2, and a scrawny, ashen-skinned boy who must be from District 3. Even now, as he sits there fiddling with some kind of plastic box, he\'92s easily ignored in the presence of his large and domineering companions. But he must be of some value or they wouldn\'92t have bothered to let him live. Still, seeing him only adds to my sense of unease over why the Careers would possibly leave him as a guard, why they have allowed him to live at all. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 All four tributes seem to still be recovering from the tracker jacker attack. Even from here, I can see the large swollen lumps on their bodies. They must not have had the sense to remove the stingers, or if they did, not known about the leaves that healed them. Apparently, whatever medicines they found in the Cornucopia have been ineffective. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 The Cornucopia sits in its original position, but its insides have been picked clean. Most of the supplies, held in crates, burlap sacks, and plastic bins, are piled neatly in a pyramid in what seems a questionable distance from the camp. Others are sprinkled around the perimeter of the pyramid, almost mimicking the layout of supplies around the Cornucopia at the onset of the Games. A canopy of netting that, aside from discouraging birds, seems to be useless shelters the pyramid itself. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 The whole setup is completely perplexing. The distance, the netting, and the presence of the boy from District 3. One thing\'92s for sure, destroying those supplies is not going to be as simple as it looks. Some other factor is at play here, and I\'92d better stay put until I figure out what it is. My guess is the pyramid is booby-trapped in some manner. I think of concealed pits, descending nets, a \
thread that when broken sends a poisonous dart into your heart. Really, the possibilities are endless. \
While I am mulling over my options, I hear Cato shout out. He\'92s pointing up to the woods, far beyond me, and without turning I know that Rue must have set the first campfire. We\'92d made sure to gather enough green wood to make the smoke noticeable. The Careers begin to arm themselves at once. \
An argument breaks out. It\'92s loud enough for me to hear that it concerns whether or not the boy from District 3 should stay or accompany them. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93He\'92s coming. We need him in the woods, and his job\'92s done here anyway. No one can touch those supplies,\'94 says Cato. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93What about Lover Boy?\'94 says the boy from District 1. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa705
\cf0 \'93I keep telling you, forget about him. I know where I cut him. It\'92s a miracle he hasn\'92t bled to death yet. At any rate, he\'92s in no shape to raid us,\'94 says Cato. \
\pard\pardeftab720\qc
\cf0 So Peeta is out there in the woods, wounded badly. But I \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 am still in the dark on what motivated him to betray the Careers. \
\'93Come on,\'94 says Cato. He thrusts a spear into the hands of the boy from District 3, and they head off in the direction of the fire. The last thing I hear as they enter the woods is Cato saying, \'93When we find her, I kill her in my own way, and no one interferes.\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Somehow I don\'92t think he\'92s talking about Rue. She didn\'92t drop a nest of tracker jackers on him. \
I stay put for a half an hour or so, trying to figure out what to do about the supplies. The one advantage I have with the bow and arrow is distance. I could send a flaming arrow into the pyramid easily enough \'97 I\'92m a good enough shot to get it through those openings in the net \'97 but there\'92s no guarantee it would catch. More likely it\'92d just burn itself out and then what? I\'92d have achieved nothing and given them far too much information about myself. That I was here, that I have an accomplice, that I can use the bow and arrow with accuracy. \
There\'92s no alternative. I\'92m going to have to get in closer \
and see if I can\'92t discover what exactly protects the supplies. In fact, I\'92m just about to reveal myself when a movement catches my eye. Several hundred yards to my right, I see someone emerge from the woods. For a second, I think it\'92s Rue, but then I recognize Foxface \'97 she\'92s the one we couldn\'92t remember this morning \'97 creeping out onto the plain. When she decides it\'92s safe, she runs for the pyramid, with quick, small steps. Just before she reaches the circle of supplies that have been littered around the pyramid, she stops, searches the ground, and carefully places her feet on a spot. Then she begins to approach the pyramid with strange little hops, sometimes landing on one foot, teetering slightly, sometimes risking a few steps. At one point, she launches up in the air, over a small barrel and lands poised on her tiptoes. But she overshot slightly, and her momentum throws her forward. I hear her give a sharp squeal as her hands hit the ground, but nothing happens. In a moment, she\'92s regained her feet and continues until she has reached the bulk of the supplies. \
So, I\'92m right about the booby trap, but it\'92s clearly more complex than I had imagined. I was right about the girl, too. How wily is she to have discovered this path into the food and to be able to replicate it so neatly? She fills her \
pack, taking a few items from a variety of containers, crackers from a crate, a handful of apples from a burlap sack that hangs suspended from a rope off the side of a bin. But only a handful from each, not enough to tip off that the food is missing. Not enough to cause suspicion. And then she\'92s doing her odd little dance back out of the circle and scampering into the woods again, safe and sound. \
I realize I\'92m grinding my teeth in frustration. Foxface has confirmed what I\'92d already guessed. But what sort of trap have they laid that requires such dexterity? Has so many trigger points? Why did she squeal so as her hands made contact with the earth? You\'92d have thought . . . and slowly it begins to dawn on me . . . you\'92d have thought the very ground was going to explode. \
\'93It\'92s mined,\'94 I whisper. That explains everything. The Careers\'92 willingness to leave their supplies, Foxface\'92s reaction, the involvement of the boy from District 3, where they have the factories, where they make televisions and automobiles and explosives. But where did he get them? In the supplies? That\'92s not the sort of weapon the Gamemakers usually provide, given that they like to see the tributes draw blood personally. I slip out of \
the bushes and cross to one of the round metal plates that lifted the tributes into the arena. The ground around it has been dug up and patted back down. The land mines were disabled after the sixty seconds we stood on the plates, but the boy from District 3 must have managed to reactivate them. I\'92ve never seen anyone in the Games do that. I bet it came as a shock even to the Gamemakers. \
Well, hurray for the boy from District 3 for putting one over on them, but what am I supposed to do now? Obviously, I can\'92t go strolling into that mess without blowing myself sky-high. As for sending in a burning arrow, that\'92s more laughable than ever. The mines are set off by pressure. It doesn\'92t have to be a lot, either. One year, a girl dropped her token, a small wooden ball, while she was at her plate, and they literally had to scrape bits of her off the ground. \
My arm\'92s pretty good, I might be able to chuck some rocks in there and set off what? Maybe one mine? That could start a chain reaction. Or could it? Would the boy from District 3 have placed the mines in such a way that a single mine would not disturb the others? Thereby protecting the supplies but ensuring the death of the \
invader. Even if I only blew up one mine, I\'92d draw the Careers back down on me for sure. And anyway, what am I thinking? There\'92s that net, clearly strung to deflect any such attack. Besides, what I\'92d really need is to throw about thirty rocks in there at once, setting off a big chain reaction, demolishing the whole lot. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I glance back up at the woods. The smoke from Rue\'92s second fire is wafting toward the sky. By now, the Careers have probably begun to suspect some sort of trick. Time is running out. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 There is a solution to this, I know there is, if I can only focus hard enough. I stare at the pyramid, the bins, the crates, too heavy to topple over with an arrow. Maybe one contains cooking oil, and the burning arrow idea is reviving when I realize I could end up losing all twelve of my arrows and not get a direct hit on an oil bin, since I\'92d just be guessing. I\'92m genuinely thinking of trying to re-create Foxface\'92s trip up to the pyramid in hopes of finding a new means of destruction when my eyes light on the burlap bag of apples. I could sever the rope in one shot, didn\'92t I do as much in the Training Center? It\'92s a big bag, but it still might only be good for one explosion. If only I could free the apples themselves . . . \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I know what to do. I move into range and give myself three arrows to get the job done. I place my feet carefully, block out the rest of the world as I take meticulous aim, The first arrow tears through the side of the bag near the top, leaving a split in the burlap. The second widens it to a gaping hole. I can see the first apple teetering when I let the third arrow go, catching the torn flap of burlap and ripping it from the bag. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 For a moment, everything seems frozen in time. Then the apples spill to the ground and I\'92m blown backward into the air. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\qc

\b \cf0 End of Chapter 
\b0 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sa570\qc

\b \cf0 Chapter 17. 
\b0 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 The impact with the hard-packed earth of the plain knocks the wind out of me. My backpack does little to soften the blow. Fortunately my quiver has caught in the crook of my elbow, sparing both itself and my shoulder, and my bow is locked in my grasp. The ground still shakes with explosions. I can\'92t hear them. I can\'92t hear anything at the moment. But the apples must have set off enough mines, causing debris to activate the others. I manage to shield my face with my arms as shattered bits of matter, some of it burning, rain down around me. An acrid smoke fills the air, which is not the best remedy for someone trying to regain the ability to breathe. \
After about a minute, the ground stops vibrating. I roll on my side and allow myself a moment of satisfaction the sight of the smoldering wreckage that was recently the pyramid. The Careers aren\'92t likely to salvage anything out of that. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I\'92d better get out of here, I think. They\'92ll be making a beeline for the place. But once I\'92m on my feet, I realize escape may not be so simple. I\'92m dizzy. Not the slightly wobbly kind, but the kind that sends the trees swooping \
around you and causes the earth to move in waves under your feet. \
I take a few steps and somehow wind up on my hands and knees. I wait a few minutes to let it pass, but it doesn\'92t. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Panic begins to set in. I can\'92t stay here. Flight is essential. But I can neither walk nor hear. I place a hand to my left ear, the one that was turned toward the blast, and it comes away bloody. Have I gone deaf from the explosion? The idea frightens me. I rely as much on my ears as my eyes as a hunter, maybe more at times. But I can\'92t let my fear show. Absolutely, positively, I am live on every screen in Panem. \
No blood trails, I tell myself, and manage to pull my hood up over my head, tie the cord under my chin with uncooperative fingers. That should help soak up the blood. I can\'92t walk, but can I crawl? I move forward tentatively. Yes, if I go very slowly, I can crawl. Most of the woods will offer insufficient cover. My only hope is to make it back to Rue\'92s copse and conceal myself in greenery. I can\'92t get caught out here on my hands and knees in the open. Not only will I face death, it\'92s sure to \
be a long and painful one at Cato\'92s hand. The thought of Prim having to watch that keeps me doggedly inching my way toward the hideout. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Another blast knocks me flat on my face. A stray mine, set off by some collapsing crate. This happens twice more. I\'92m reminded of those last few kernels that burst when Prim and I pop corn over the fire at home. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 To say I make it in the nick of time is an understatement. I have literally just dragged myself into the tangle of hushes at the base of the trees when there\'92s Cato, barreling onto the plain, soon followed by his companions. His rage is so extreme it might be comical \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'97 so people really do tear out their hair and beat the ground with their fists \'97 if I didn\'92t know that it was aimed at me, at what I have done to him. Add to that my proximity, my inability to run or defend myself, and in fact, the whole thing has me terrified. I\'92m glad my hiding place makes it impossible for the cameras to get a close shot of me because I\'92m biting my nails like there\'92s no tomorrow. Gnawing off the last bits of nail polish, trying to keep my teeth from chattering. \
The boy from District 3 throws stones into the ruins and \
must have declared all the mines activated because the Careers are approaching the wreckage. \
Cato has finished the first phase of his tantrum and takes out his anger on the smoking remains by kicking open various containers. The other tributes are poking around in the mess, looking for anything to salvage, but there\'92s nothing. The boy from District 3 has done his job too well. This idea must occur to Cato, too, because he turns on the boy and appears to be shouting at him. The boy from District 3 only has time to turn and run before Cato catches him in a headlock from behind. I can see the muscles ripple in Cato\'92s arms as he sharply jerks the boy\'92s head to the side. \
It\'92s that quick. The death of the boy from District 3. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 The other two Careers seem to be trying to calm Cato down. I can tell he wants to return to the woods, but they keep pointing at the sky, which puzzles me until I realize, Of course. They think whoever set off the explosions is dead. \
They don\'92t know about the arrows and the apples. They assume the booby trap was faulty, but that the tribute \
who blew up the supplies was killed doing it. If there was a cannon shot, it could have been easily lost in the subsequent explosions. The shattered remains of the thief removed by hovercraft. They retire to the far side of the lake to allow the Gamemakers to retrieve the body of the boy from District 3. And they wait. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 I suppose a cannon goes off. A hovercraft appears and takes the dead boy. The sun dips below the horizon. Night falls. Up in the sky, I see the seal and know the anthem must have begun. A moment of darkness. They show the boy from District 3. They show the boy from District 10, who must have died this morning. Then the seal reappears. So, now they know. The bomber survived. In the seal\'92s light, I can see Cato and the girl from District 2 put on their night-vision glasses. The boy from District 1 ignites a tree branch for a torch, illuminating the grim determination on all their faces. The Careers stride back into the woods to hunt. The dizziness has subsided and while my left ear is still deafened, I can hear a ringing in my right, which seems a good sign. There\'92s no point in leaving my hiding place, though. I\'92m about as safe as I can be, here at the crime scene. They probably think the bomber has a two-or three-hour lead on them. Still it\'92s a long time before I risk moving. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 The first thing I do is dig out my own glasses and put them on, which relaxes me a little, to have at least one of my hunter\'92s senses working. I drink some water and wash the blood from my ear. Fearing the smell of meat will draw unwanted predators \'97 fresh blood is bad enough \'97 I make a good meal out of the greens and roots and berries Rue and I gathered today. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Where is my little ally? Did she make it back to the rendezvous point? Is she worried about me? At least, the sky has shown we\'92re both alive. \
I run through the surviving tributes on my fingers. The boy from 1, both from 2, Foxface, both from 11 and 12. Just eight of us. The betting must be getting really hot in the Capitol. They\'92ll be doing special features on each of us now. Probably interviewing our friends and families. It\'92s been a long time since a tribute from District 12 made it into the top eight. And now there are two of us. Although from what Cato said, Peeta\'92s on his way out. Not that Cato is the final word on anything. Didn\'92t he just lose his entire stash of supplies? \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571
\cf0 Let the Seventy-fourth Hunger Games begin, Cato, I think. Let them begin for real. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 A cold breeze has sprung up. I reach for my sleeping bag before I remember I left it with Rue. I was supposed to pick up another one, but what with the mines and all, I forgot. I begin to shiver. Since roosting overnight in a tree isn\'92t sensible anyway, I scoop out a hollow under the bushes and cover myself with leaves and pine needles. I\'92m still freezing. I lay my sheet of plastic over my upper body and position my backpack to block the wind. It\'92s a little better. I begin to have more sympathy for the girl from District 8 that lit the fire that first night. But now it\'92s me who needs to grit my teeth and tough it out until morning. More leaves, more pine needles. I pull my arms inside my jacket and tuck my knees up to my chest. Somehow, I drift off to sleep. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 When I open my eyes, the world looks slightly fractured, and it takes a minute to realize that the sun must be well up and the glasses fragmenting my vision. As I sit up and remove them, I hear a laugh somewhere near the lake and freeze. The laugh\'92s distorted, but the fact that it registered at all means I must be regaining my hearing. Yes, my right ear can hear again, although it\'92s still ringing. As for my left ear, well, at least the bleeding has stopped. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I peer through the bushes, afraid the Careers have returned, trapping me here for an indefinite time. No, it\'92s Foxface, standing in the rubble of the pyramid and laughing. She\'92s smarter than the Careers, actually finding a few useful items in the ashes. A metal pot. A knife blade. I\'92m perplexed by her amusement until I realize that with the Careers\'92 stores eliminated, she might actually stand a chance. Just like the rest of us. It crosses my mind to reveal myself and enlist her as a second ally against that pack. But I rule it out. There\'92s something about that sly grin that makes me sure that befriending Foxface would ultimately get me a knife in the back. With that in mind, this might be an excellent time to shoot her. But she\'92s heard something, not me, because her head turns away, toward the drop-off, and she sprints for the woods. I wait. No one, nothing shows up. Still, if Foxface thought it was dangerous, maybe it\'92s time for me to get out of here, too. Besides, I\'92m eager to tell Rue about the pyramid. \
Since I\'92ve no idea where the Careers are, the route back by the stream seems as good as any. I hurry, loaded bow in one hand, a hunk of cold groosling in the other, because I\'92m famished now, and not just for leaves and berries but for the fat and protein in the meat. The trip to \
the stream is uneventful. Once there, I refill my water and wash, taking particular care with my injured ear. Then I travel uphill using the stream as a guide. At one point, I find boot prints in the mud along the bank. The Careers have been here, but not for a while. The prints are deep because they were made in soft mud, but now they\'92re nearly dry in the hot sun. I haven\'92t been careful enough about my own tracks, counting on a light tread and the pine needles to conceal my prints. Now I strip off my boots and socks and go barefoot up the bed of the stream. \
The cool water has an invigorating effect on my body, my spirits. I shoot two fish, easy pickings in this slow-moving stream, and go ahead and eat one raw even though I\'92ve just had the groosling. The second I\'92ll save for Rue. \
Gradually, subtly, the ringing in my right ear diminishes until it\'92s gone entirely. I find myself pawing at my left ear periodically, trying to clean away whatever deadens its ability to collect sounds. If there\'92s improvement, it\'92s undetectable. I can\'92t adjust to deafness in the ear. It makes me feel off-balanced and defenseless to my left. Blind even. My head keeps turning to the injured side, as my right ear tries to compensate for the wall of \
nothingness where yesterday there was a constant flow of information. The more time that passes, the less hopeful I am that this is an injury that will heal. \
When I reach the site of our first meeting, I feel certain it\'92s been undisturbed. There\'92s no sign of Rue, not on the ground or in the trees. This is odd. By now she should have returned, as it\'92s midday. Undoubtedly, she spent the night in a tree somewhere. What else could she do with no light and the Careers with their night-vision glasses tramping around the woods. And the third fire she was supposed to set \'97 although I forgot to check for it last night \'97 was the farthest from our site of all. She\'92s probably just being cautious about making her way back. I wish she\'92d hurry, because I don\'92t want to hang around here too long. I want to spend the afternoon traveling to higher ground, hunting as we go. But there\'92s nothing really for me to do but wait. \
I wash the blood out of my jacket and hair and clean my ever-growing list of wounds. The burns are much better but I use a bit of medicine on them anyway. The main thing to worry about now is keeping out infection. I go ahead and eat the second fish. It isn\'92t going to last long in this hot sun, but it should be easy enough to spear a \
few more for Rue. If she would just show up. \
Feeling too vulnerable on the ground with my lopsided hearing, I scale a tree to wait. If the Careers show up, this will be a fine place to shoot them from. The sun moves slowly. I do things to pass the time. Chew leaves and apply them to my stings that are deflated but still tender. Comb through my damp hair with my fingers and braid it. Lace my boots back up. Check over my bow and remaining nine arrows. Test my left ear repeatedly for signs of life by rustling a leaf near it, but without good results. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Despite the groosling and the fish, my stomach\'92s growling, and I know I\'92m going to have what we call a hollow day back in District 12. That\'92s a day where no matter what you put in your belly, it\'92s never enough. Having nothing to do but sit in a tree makes it worse, so I decide to give into it. After all, I\'92ve lost a lot of weight in the arena, I need some extra calories. And having the bow and arrows makes me far more confident about my future prospects. \
I slowly peel and eat a handful of nuts. My last cracker. The groosling neck. That\'92s good because it takes time to \
pick clean. Finally, a groosling wing and the bird is history. But it\'92s a hollow day, and even with all that I start daydreaming about food. Particularly the decadent dishes served in the Capitol. The chicken in creamy orange sauce. The cakes and pudding. Bread with butter. Noodles in green sauce. The lamb and dried plum stew. I suck on a few mint leaves and tell myself to get over it. Mint is good because we drink mint tea after supper often, so it tricks my stomach into thinking eating time is over. Sort of. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Dangling up in the tree, with the sun warming me, a mouthful of mint, my bow and arrows at hand . . . this is the most relaxed I\'92ve been since I\'92ve entered the arena. If only Rue would show up, and we could clear out. As the shadows grow, so does my restlessness. By late afternoon, I\'92ve resolved to go looking for her. I can at least visit the spot where she set the third fire and see if there are any clues to her whereabouts. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571
\cf0 Before I go, I scatter a few mint leaves around our old campfire. Since we gathered these some distance away, Rue will understand I\'92ve been here, while they\'92ll mean nothing to the Careers. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 In less than an hour, I\'92m at the place where we agreed to have the third fire and I know something has gone amiss. The wood has been neatly arranged, expertly interspersed with tinder, but it has never been lit. Rue set up the fire but never made it back here. Somewhere between the second column of smoke I spied before I blew up the supplies and this point, she ran into trouble. \
I have to remind myself she\'92s still alive. Or is she? Could the cannon shot announcing her death have come in the wee hours of the morning when even my good ear was too broken to pick it up? Will she appear in the sky tonight? No, I refuse to believe it. There could be a hundred other explanations. She could have lost her way. Run into a pack of predators or another tribute, like Thresh, and had to hide. Whatever happened, I\'92m almost certain she\'92s stuck out there, somewhere between the second fire and the unlit one at my feet. Something is keeping her up a tree. \
I think I\'92ll go hunt it down. \
It\'92s a relief to be doing something after sitting around all afternoon. I creep silently through the shadows, letting them \
conceal me. But nothing seems suspicious. There\'92s no sign of any kind of struggle, no disruption of the needles on the ground. I\'92ve stopped for just a moment when I hear it. I have to cock my head around to the side to be sure, but there it is again. Rue\'92s four-note tune coming out of a mockingjay\'92s mouth. The one that means she\'92s all right. \
I grin and move in the direction of the bird. Another just a short distance ahead, picks up on the handful of notes. Rue has been singing to them, and recently. Otherwise they\'92d have taken up some other song. My eyes lift up into the trees, searching for a sign of her. I swallow and sing softly back, hoping she\'92ll know it\'92s safe to join me. A mockingjay repeats the melody to me. And that\'92s when I hear the scream. \
It\'92s a child\'92s scream, a young girl\'92s scream, there\'92s no one in the arena capable of making that sound except Rue. And now I\'92m running, knowing this may be a trap, knowing the three Careers may be poised to attack me, but I can\'92t help myself. There\'92s another high-pitched cry, this time my name. \'93Katniss! Katniss!\'94 \
\'93Rue!\'94 I shout back, so she knows I\'92m near. So, they \
know I\'92m near, and hopefully the girl who has attacked them with tracker jackers and gotten an eleven they still can\'92t explain will be enough to pull their attention away from her. \'93Rue! I\'92m coming!\'94 \
When I break into the clearing, she\'92s on the ground, hopelessly entangled in a net. She just has time to reach her hand through the mesh and say my name before the spear enters her body. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\qc

\b \cf0 End of Chapter 
\b0 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sa570\qc

\b \cf0 Chapter 18. 
\b0 \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 The boy from District 1 dies before he can pull out the spear. My arrow drives deeply into the center of his neck. He falls to his knees and halves the brief remainder of his life by yanking out the arrow and drowning in his own blood. I\'92m reloaded, shifting my aim from side to side, while I shout at Rue, \'93Are there more? Are there more?\'94 \
She has to say no several times before I hear it. Rue has rolled to her side, her body curved in and around the spear. I shove the boy away from her and pull out my knife, freeing her from the net. One look at the wound and I know it\'92s far beyond my capacity to heal, beyond anyone\'92s probably. The spearhead is buried up to the shaft in her stomach. I crouch before her, staring helplessly at the embedded weapon. There\'92s no point in comforting words, in telling her she\'92ll be all right. She\'92s no fool. Her hand reaches out and I clutch it like a lifeline. As if it\'92s me who\'92s dying instead of Rue. \
\'93You blew up the food?\'94 she whispers. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 \'93Every last bit,\'94 I say. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sa570
\cf0 \'93You have to win,\'94 she says. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93I\'92m going to. Going to win for both of us now,\'94 I promise. I hear a cannon and look up. It must be for the boy from District 1. \'93Don\'92t go.\'94 Rue tightens her grip on my hand. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93Course not. Staying right here,\'94 I say. I move in closer to her, pulling her head onto my lap. I gently brush the dark, thick hair back behind her ear. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 \'93Sing,\'94 she says, but I barely catch the word. \
Sing? I think. Sing what? I do know a few songs. Believe it or not, there was once music in my house, too. Music I helped make. My father pulled me in with that remarkable voice \'97 but I haven\'92t sung much since he died. Except when Prim is very sick. Then I sing her the same songs she liked as a baby. \
Sing. My throat is tight with tears, hoarse from smoke and fatigue. But if this is Prim\'92s, I mean, Rue\'92s last request, I have to at least try. The song that comes to me is a simple lullaby, one we sing fretful, hungry babies to sleep with, It\'92s old, very old I think. Made up long ago \
in our hills. What my music teacher calls a mountain air. But the words are easy and soothing, promising tomorrow will be more hopeful than this awful piece of time we call today. \
I give a small cough, swallow hard, and begin: \
Deep in the meadow, under the willow A bed of grass, a soft green pillow Lay down your head, and close your sleepy eyes And when again they open, the sun will rise. \
Here it\'92s safe, here it\'92s warm Here the daisies guard you from every harm Here your dreams are sweet and tomorrow brings them true Here is the place where I love you. \
Rue\'92s eyes have fluttered shut. Her chest moves but only slightly. My throat releases the tears and they slide down my cheeks. But I have to finish the song for her. \
Deep in the meadow, hidden far away A cloak of leaves, a moonbeam ray Forget your woes and let your troubles lay \
And when again it\'92s morning, they\'92ll wash away. \
Here it\'92s safe, here it\'92s warm Here the daisies guard you from every harm \
The final lines are barely audible. \
Here your dreams are sweet and tomorrow brings them true Here is the place where I love you. \

\cf0 Everything\'92s still and quiet. Then, almost eerily, the mockingjays take up my song. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 For a moment, I sit there, watching my tears drip down on her face. Rue\'92s cannon fires. I lean forward and press my lips against her temple. Slowly, as if not to wake her, I lay her head back on the ground and release her hand. \
They\'92ll want me to clear out now. So they can collect the bodies. And there\'92s nothing to stay for. I roll the boy from District 1 onto his face and take his pack, retrieve the arrow that ended his life. I cut Rue\'92s pack from her back as well, knowing she\'92d want me to have it but leave the spear in her stomach. Weapons in bodies will be \
transported to the hovercraft. I\'92ve no use for a spear, so the sooner it\'92s gone from the arena the better. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I can\'92t stop looking at Rue, smaller than ever, a baby animal curled up in a nest of netting. I can\'92t bring myself to leave her like this. Past harm, but seeming utterly defenseless. To hate the boy from District 1, who also appears so vulnerable in death, seems inadequate. It\'92s the Capitol I hate, for doing this to all of us. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Gale\'92s voice is in my head. His ravings against the Capitol no longer pointless, no longer to be ignored. Rue\'92s death has forced me to confront my own fury against the cruelty, the injustice they inflict upon us. But here, even more strongly than at home, I feel my impotence. There\'92s no way to take revenge on the Capitol. Is there? \
Then I remember Peeta\'92s words on the roof. \'93Only I keep wishing I could think of a way to . . . to show the Capital they don\'92t own me. That I\'92m more than just a piece in their Games.\'94 And for the first time, I understand what he means. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I want to do something, right here, right now, to shame them, to make them accountable, to show the Capitol \
that whatever they do or force us to do there is a part of every tribute they can\'92t own. That Rue was more than a piece in their Games. And so am I. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 A few steps into the woods grows a bank of wildflowers. Perhaps they are really weeds of some sort, but they have blossoms in beautiful shades of violet and yellow and white. I gather up an armful and come back to Rue\'92s side. Slowly, one stem at a time, I decorate her body in the flowers. Covering the ugly wound. Wreathing her face. Weaving her hair with bright colors. \
They\'92ll have to show it. Or, even if they choose to turn the cameras elsewhere at this moment, they\'92ll have to bring them back when they collect the bodies and everyone will see her then and know I did it. I step back and take a last look at Rue. She could really be asleep in that meadow after all. \
\'93Bye, Rue,\'94 I whisper. I press the three middle fingers of my left hand against my lips and hold them out in her direction. Then I walk away without looking back. \
The birds fall silent. Somewhere, a mockingjay gives the warning whistle that precedes the hovercraft. I don\'92t \
know how it knows. It must hear things that humans can\'92t. I pause, my eyes focused on what\'92s ahead, not what\'92s happening behind me. It doesn\'92t take long, then the general birdsong begins again and I know she\'92s gone. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Another mockingjay, a young one by the look of it, lands on a branch before me and bursts out Rue\'92s melody. \
My song, the hovercraft, were too unfamiliar for this novice to pick up, but it has mastered her handful of notes. The ones that mean she\'92s safe. \
\'93Good and safe,\'94 I say as I pass under its branch. \'93We don\'92t have to worry about her now.\'94 Good and safe. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571
\cf0 I\'92ve no idea where to go. The brief sense of home I had that one night with Rue has vanished. My feet wander this way and that until sunset. I\'92m not afraid, not even watchful. Which makes me an easy target. Except I\'92d kill anyone I met on sight. Without emotion or the slightest tremor in my hands. My hatred of the Capitol has not lessened my hatred of my competitors in the least. Especially the Careers. They, at least, can be made to pay for Rue\'92s death. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 No one materializes though. There aren\'92t many of us left and it\'92s a big arena. Soon they\'92ll be pulling out some other device to force us together. But there\'92s been enough gore today. Perhaps we\'92ll even get to sleep. \
I\'92m about to haul my packs into a tree to make camp when a silver parachute floats down and lands in front of me. A gift from a sponsor. But why now? I\'92ve been in fairly good shape with supplies. Maybe Haymitch\'92s noticed my despondency and is trying to cheer me up a bit. Or could it be something to help my ear? \
I open the parachute and find a small loaf of bread. It\'92s not the fine white Capitol stuff. It\'92s made of dark ration grain and shaped in a crescent. Sprinkled with seeds. I flash back to Peeta\'92s lesson on the various district breads in the Training Center. This bread came from District 11. I cautiously lift the still warm loaf. What must it have cost the people of District 11 who can\'92t even feed themselves? How many would\'92ve had to do without to scrape up a coin to put in the collection for this one loaf? It had been meant for Rue, surely. But instead of pulling the gift when she died, they\'92d authorized Haymitch to give it to me. As a thank-you? Or because, like me, they don\'92t like to let debts go unpaid? For whatever reason, \
this is a first. A district gift to a tribute who\'92s not your own. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I lift my face and step into the last falling rays of sunlight. \'93My thanks to the people of District Eleven,\'94 I say. I want them to know I know where it came from. That the full value of their gift has been recognized. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I climb dangerously high into a tree, not for safety but to get as far away from today as I can. My sleeping bag is rolled neatly in Rue\'92s pack. Tomorrow I\'92ll sort through the supplies. Tomorrow I\'92ll make a new plan. But tonight, all I can do is strap myself in and take tiny bites of the bread. It\'92s good. It tastes of home. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Soon the seal\'92s in the sky, the anthem plays in my right ear. I see the boy from District 1, Rue. That\'92s all for tonight. Six of us left, I think. Only six. With the bread still locked in my hands, I fall asleep at once. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Sometimes when things are particularly bad, my brain will give me a happy dream. A visit with my father in the woods. An hour of sunlight and cake with Prim. Tonight it sends me Rue, still decked in her flowers, perched in a high sea of trees, trying to teach me to talk to the \
mockingjays. I see no sign of her wounds, no blood, just a bright, laughing girl. She sings songs I\'92ve never heard in a clear, melodic voice. On and on. Through the night. There\'92s a drowsy in-between period when I can hear the last few strains of her music although she\'92s lost in the leaves. When I fully awaken, I\'92m momentarily comforted. I try to hold on to the peaceful feeling of the dream, but it quickly slips away, leaving me sadder and lonelier than ever. \
Heaviness infuses my whole body, as if there\'92s liquid lead in my veins. I\'92ve lost the will to do the simplest tasks, to do anything but lie here, staring unblinkingly through the canopy of leaves. For several hours, I remain motionless. As usual, it\'92s the thought of Prim\'92s anxious face as she watches me on the screens back home that breaks me from my lethargy. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 I give myself a series of simple commands to follow, like \'93Now you have to sit up, Katniss. Now you have to drink water, Katniss.\'94 I act on the orders with slow, robotic motions. \'93Now you have to sort the packs, Katniss.\'94 \

\cf0 1 has several knives, two spare spearheads, a flashlight, a small leather pouch, a first-aid kit, a full bottle of water, and a pack of dried fruit. A pack of dried fruit! Out of all he might have chosen from. To me, this is a sign of extreme arrogance. Why bother to carry food when you have such a bounty back at camp? When you will kill your enemies so quickly you\'92ll be home before you\'92re hungry? I can only hope the other Careers traveled so lightly when it came to food and now find themselves with nothing. \
Speaking of which, my own supply is running low. I finish off the loaf from District 11 and the last of the rabbit. How quickly the food disappears. All I have left are Rue\'92s roots and nuts, the boy\'92s dried fruit, and one strip of beef. Now you have to hunt, Katniss, I tell myself. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571
\cf0 I obediently consolidate the supplies I want into my pack. After I climb down the tree, I conceal the boy\'92s knives and spearheads in a pile of rocks so that no one else can use them. I\'92ve lost my bearings what with all the wandering around I did yesterday evening, but I try and head back in the general direction of the stream. I know I\'92m on course when I come across Rue\'92s third, unlit fire. \

\cf0 perched in the trees and take out three before they know what hit them. I return to Rue\'92s signal fire and start it up, not caring about the excessive smoke. Where are you, Cato? I think as I roast the birds and Rue\'92s roots. I\'92m waiting right here. \
Who knows where the Careers are now? Either too far to reach me or too sure this is a trick or ... is it possible? Too scared of me? Figured out I blew up the supplies and killed their fellow Career? Possibly they think Thresh did this. Wouldn\'92t he be more likely to revenge Rue\'92s death than I would? Being from the same district? Not that he ever took any interest in her. \

\cf0 But I told Rue I\'92d be there. For both of us. And somehow that seems even more important than the vow I gave Prim. \

Now I am determined to revenge her, to make her loss unforgettable, and I can only do that by winning and thereby making myself unforgettable. \

\cf0 screens most than I care. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Eventually, I wrap up my food and go back to the stream to replenish my water and gather some. But the heaviness from the morning drapes back over me and even though it\'92s only early evening, I climb a tree and settle in for the night. My brain begins to replay the events from yesterday. I keep seeing Rue speared, my arrow piercing the boy\'92s neck. I don\'92t know why I should even care about the boy. \
Then I realize . . . he was my first kill. \
Along with other statistics they report to help people place their bets, every tribute has a list of kills. I guess technically I\'92d get credited for Glimmer and the girl from District 4, too, for dumping that nest on them. But the boy from District 1 was the first person I knew would die because of my actions. Numerous animals have lost their lives at my hands, but only one human. I hear Gale saying, \'93How different can it be, really?\'94 \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Amazingly similar in the execution. A bow pulled, an arrow shot. Entirely different in the aftermath. I killed a boy whose name I don\'92t even know. Somewhere his \
family is weeping for him. His friends call for my blood. Maybe he had a girlfriend who really believed he would come back . . . \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 But then I think of Rue\'92s still body and I\'92m able to banish the boy from my mind. At least, for now. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 It\'92s been an uneventful day according to the sky. No deaths. I wonder how long we\'92ll get until the next catastrophe drives us back together. If it\'92s going to be tonight, I want to get some sleep first. I cover my good ear to block out the strains of the anthem, but then I hear the trumpets and sit straight up in anticipation. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571
\cf0 For the most part, the only communication the tributes get from outside the arena is the nightly death toll. But occasionally, there will be trumpets followed by an announcement. Usually, this will be a call to a feast. When food is scarce, the Gamemakers will invite the players to a banquet, somewhere known to all like the Cornucopia, as an inducement to gather and fight. Sometimes there is a feast and sometimes there\'92s nothing but a loaf of stale bread for the tributes to compete for. I wouldn\'92t go in for the food, but this could be an ideal time to take out a few competitors. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa570
\cf0 Claudius Templesmith\'92s voice booms down from overhead, congratulating the six of us who remain. But he is not inviting us to a feast. He\'92s saying something very confusing. There\'92s been a rule change in the Games. A rule change! That in itself is mind bending since we don\'92t really have any rules to speak of except don\'92t step off your circle for sixty seconds and the unspoken rule about not eating one another. Under the new rule, both tributes from the same district will be declared winners if they are the last two alive. Claudius pauses, as if he knows we\'92re not getting it, and repeats the change again. \
\pard\pardeftab720\ri3394\sl571\sa570
\cf0 The news sinks in. Two tributes can win this year. If they\'92re from the same district. Both can live. Both of us can live. \
\pard\pardeftab720\sl571\sa1137
